title: The Shadow of the Prussians
events:
The cry echoes through the darkened alley, drawing attention to the Poivrière bar. Inside, the fireplace has gone cold. Two men lie dead on the floor, one slumped against the wall, the other sprawled across the hearth. A third body is in the center of the room, and a fourth, wounded man, stands frozen in the doorway, blood trickling down his forehead. The air is thick with the scent of gunpowder and spilled wine.

"Self-defense!" the wounded man shouts, his voice hoarse, as he stumbles back, trying to escape.

A crowd gathers as he is subdued. In a final, gasping breath, the soldier says, "Lacheneur... revenge... the Prussians..."

William Murdoch arrives at the scene, his eyes scanning the room with quiet intensity. He kneels beside the dead soldier, noting the precise placement of the wounds and the angle of entry. His gloved hand lifts the man's greatcoat, revealing a small but neat insignia on the buttons: 92nd Régiment de Ligne.

He turns to the officer beside him. "This man was not a target. He was a witness."

The officer frowns. "Witness to what?"

"To something he saw, perhaps something that would have changed the course of events."

Murdoch photographs the crime scene with his new Kodak, careful to capture the spatial relationships and the positions of the bodies. He marks the bullet holes in the wall, noting their heights and trajectories. One of the dead men, dressed in civilian clothes, has a small bloodied knife in his hand. The other has a gunshot wound to the chest—consistent with a close-range shot.

The wounded man, identified as Pierre Morel, is taken to a nearby clinic. His story, however, is riddled with inconsistencies. He claims he was attacked in the bar, that the other two men were the aggressors, that he fired in self-defense.

Murdoch listens, his brow furrowed.

At the clinic, Murdoch interviews Pierre Morel. The man is feverish, but lucid enough to speak.

"I didn't want to be here," Morel says, wiping sweat from his brow. "I was told someone from my regiment was hiding out. I thought I was helping the cause."

"What cause was that?" Murdoch asks, his tone even.

"Against the Prussians. That man—Lacheneur—was a traitor. He sold information to the enemy."

Murdoch notes the mention of Lacheneur. He had heard the name before—whispers of a double agent, a man who moved between the camps and the city like a ghost.

Murdoch visits the home of Jean Lacheneur, a merchant who had recently been under suspicion. The house is tidy, untouched by violence. However, Murdoch notices a faint odor of gunpowder in the air and discovers a small, bloodstained cloth in the waste bin. Under magnification, he finds a single hair, not his own.

He also finds a ledger with coded entries and a drawer full of letters—some written in German.

Lacheneur himself is missing.

A breakthrough comes when Murdoch cross-references the soldier's regimental number with the list of missing men from the 92nd Régiment de Ligne. The soldier, Henri Fournier, was last seen alive three nights ago, in the company of a civilian—Lacheneur.

Murdoch visits the barracks to speak with Fournier's comrades. One of them recalls a heated argument between Fournier and Lacheneur days before the man's disappearance.

"He said he was going to expose him," the soldier says. "That he was a spy."

Murdoch returns to the bar to conduct a reconstruction. He arranges the bodies in the exact positions they were found, using photographs and measurements. He uses a dummy to reenact the shooting, testing the trajectories.

One inconsistency stands out: the civilian with the knife was not in a position to stab the other dead man, who had been shot in the chest.

Murdoch also notes that the wounds on the wounded man, Morel, were defensive in nature—suggesting he had not fired the shot that killed the other man.

Murdoch interviews the barmaid, Marie, who had seen the men earlier in the evening. She describes a tense conversation between Morel and Fournier. She also mentions that Lacheneur had arrived shortly before the shooting, but had not entered.

"She looked nervous," Marie says. "Like she was waiting for something."

Murdoch asks what Lacheneur had said when he arrived.

"She said, 'It's not too late. Come with me.' Then she left."

Murdoch examines the bar's door hinges and notices the faint impressions of a boot print. It is not Morel's. He compares it to the boots found in Lacheneur's home—identical in pattern.

He also finds a small, folded note in the pocket of the dead civilian. It reads: "Midnight. Poivrière. Be there." The handwriting is not Lacheneur's.

Morel's story begins to unravel. Under pressure, he admits that he had not been attacked in the bar—he had been waiting for Fournier. He believed that Fournier had information that could clear his name in a previous scandal.

"I was desperate," Morel says, his voice breaking. "I thought if I could get him to talk, I could prove that Lacheneur was the traitor."

But Fournier, it seems, had already discovered the truth—and Lacheneur was not the traitor. He was the target.

Murdoch pieces together the sequence: Fournier had learned that Lacheneur was being framed for treason. He had gone to the bar to meet someone who could clear him—perhaps a colleague from the military.

Lacheneur, fearing exposure, had arrived first, attempting to lure Fournier into the bar and eliminate the threat.

Morel, unaware of the full story, had been sent to the bar by someone else, perhaps a rival of Lacheneur. He arrived too late, caught in the crossfire.

The real killer had been in the room all along—but not the one everyone assumed.

Murdoch finds the final clue in the soldier's pocket: a letter addressed to a Captain in the 92nd Régiment. It reads: "Meet me at Poivrière. I have proof of Lacheneur's betrayal. Come alone."

The handwriting matches that of the note found in the bar. The killer had posed as Fournier.

But who was it?

Murdoch checks the bar's ledger. One name stands out: Captain Étienne Duret, known for his bitter rivalry with Fournier. A man who had everything to gain from Fournier's death.

Murdoch confronts Duret. The captain is taken aback, but his alibi is shaky. He claims he was at a brothel that night—but the proprietor denies his presence.

Duret, cornered, finally admits the truth. He had been jealous of Fournier's rising influence. He saw an opportunity to eliminate him and frame Lacheneur.

He had impersonated Fournier at the bar, lured Morel and the real Fournier into the room, and shot the soldier in self-defense—thinking he had just killed the real traitor.

But he had made a fatal mistake: he had not noticed the soldier's identity.

Murdoch stands before the assembled officers and the press. He recounts the events with clinical precision, revealing the false identity, the setup, and the tragic misunderstandings that led to the deaths.

He explains how the wounded man had not fired the fatal shot—how the real victim was the soldier, not the accused.

"The truth," he says, "is rarely what it seems. It is not enough to see the surface. One must look deeper, understand the patterns, and test the assumptions."

As the investigation closes, Murdoch reflects on the case. He writes a report, detailing the reconstruction, the forensic evidence, and the psychological motivations.

He also adds a personal note: "In the end, it was not the weapon that betrayed the truth—but the silence between the words, the shadows cast by the lies, and the careful observation of what others overlooked."

Murdoch receives a letter from Lacheneur, who had been found hiding in the countryside. He thanks Murdoch for clearing his name and offers to help in the ongoing investigation into Prussian infiltration.

Murdoch replies with a single sentence: "Truth is a fragile thing. Handle it with care."

The case is closed. The bar is reopened. The barmaid, Marie, resumes her work, and the bar is now known as Le Bar des Ombres—The Bar of Shadows.

Murdoch walks away, his mind already turning to the next mystery. He pauses for a moment, gazing at the Poivrière from the street.

"Not all shadows are what they seem," he murmurs to himself.

The final scene is quiet. Murdoch sits at a café, sipping coffee and reading a newspaper. A headline reads: "MURDER MYSTERY SOLVED—TRAGIC CASE OF MISTAKEN IDENTITY."

He smiles slightly, tapping a finger on the table.

"Mistaken identity," he says, almost to himself. "How often does that happen in truth?"

title: The Prussian Shadow in the Poivrière
events:
The cry echoes through the narrow alley of the Rue de la Poissonnière. William Murdoch, a tall, thin man with an air of quiet authority, steps into the Poivrière bar. Inside, the scene is grim: two men lie dead near the fireplace, their bodies still warm, and a third lies in the center of the room. A fourth man, bloodied and gasping, stands in the doorway, clutching his side.  

"Self-defense! I was forced into it!" the wounded man gasps, then turns to flee. Murdoch intercepts him, pinning his arm. "You said the Prussians are coming."  

The dying soldier in the center of the room croaks, "It was Lacheneur... he lured me here... revenge..." He then collapses.

Murdoch begins by documenting the scene meticulously. He photographs the bodies, notes the position of the fire, and collects the soldier's greatcoat. The buttons are embossed with the name "Régiment de la Garde Prussienne," though no such unit has existed in the French army in years.  

He kneels beside the soldier's body, examining the wound. "A bayonet, not a pistol," he murmurs. "Fighting up close."

Lacheneur is taken to the station. He is disheveled, his hands shaking. "I didn't want this," he says. "He came to me with threats. He said he knew about my brother, who died in the war. I tried to warn him off. He said he'd report me. I panicked."  

Murdoch studies him carefully. "You say he threatened you. Did he say where he was stationed?"  

Lacheneur hesitates. "No. But he was dressed like a soldier. I thought—"  

"Thought what?"  

"That he was a soldier," Lacheneur says slowly. "I didn't think to check."

At the morgue, Murdoch works with Dr. Émile Ruelle, a forensic pathologist. "The wound on the soldier's chest is clean, from a single thrust," Ruelle says. "No hesitation. The attacker was certain."  

Murdoch nods. "And the other two men?"  

"They were stabbed post-mortem," Ruelle replies. "No defense wounds. Someone wanted to stage a fight."

Murdoch returns to the Poivrière bar at night, armed with a lantern and notebook. He walks the room, measuring distances, noting the angle of the firelight. He tests the floorboards, looking for signs of struggle.  

He finds something odd: a patch on the wall near the fireplace, slightly darker than the rest. He scrapes it with a knife. Beneath the paint, he finds a bullet hole. "A prior incident," he mutters. "The bar was the scene of another crime."

Murdoch interviews the barkeeper, a wizened old man named Pauline. He asks about the bar's history.  

"I remember, yes," Pauline says. "A few years ago, a group of men came in. Soldiers, they claimed. One was shot. I don't know who did it. The police came, asked questions. But no one was ever arrested."  

Murdon jots it down. "Did you see any of them again?"  

Pauline shrugs. "Only one. A man who used to come in often. He wore a soldier's coat, but no one knew if he was real. People called him 'The Prussian Ghost.'"

Murdoch visits the regimental records office. The name "Régiment de la Garde Prussienne" doesn't exist. He asks about soldiers who might have worn coats with similar buttons. An archivist shows him a ledger.  

"Ah," she says. "A soldier named Alphonse Duret, discharged in 1864 for desertion. He was from this area. Disappeared after that."  

Murdon frowns. "And his brother?"  

The archivist hesitates. "There was a brother, Jacques. He died in the Franco-Prussian War. A hero, they said. But no record of him being in the Garde."

Murdon returns to Lacheneur. This time, he shows him a photo of the dead soldier. "This is not a real soldier, is it?"  

Lacheneur blinks. "No. But he said he was. He showed me the coat. I believed him."  

"Why would you believe a man in a stolen uniform?"  

Lacheneur looks down. "Because his brother was a hero. Because I thought he was still noble, even if... even if he had fallen."

Murdon visits a tailor shop known for custom military uniforms. The owner, a man named Henri, is hesitant at first, but when shown the coat buttons, his face pales.  

"I made them," he says. "For a man who called himself Duret. He wanted to look like a soldier. He said it was to scare people. He used to visit this bar. The Prussian Ghost."

Murdon returns to the bar and reconstructs the scene. He arranges three chairs in the positions of the bodies. He places a mannequin in the center. He uses a small knife to simulate the bayonet thrust.  

He tests the angle of the fireplace light, the position of the door, and the height of the attacker. He notes that the attacker must have been shorter than the soldier.  

He turns to the bullet hole in the wall. He measures it, compares it to the new hole from the recent killing. They are nearly identical.

Murdon interviews the bar's regulars. One woman, Madame Leclerc, recalls a man named Alphonse who used to visit. "He was always alone. Drank too much. Sometimes, he talked about his brother. Said he was a hero. He wore that coat like it was armor."  

Murdon asks, "Did he ever threaten anyone?"  

She nods. "He threatened Lacheneur. Said he'd expose him. That he had secrets from the war. That he would ruin him."

Murdon returns to the station and confronts Lacheneur. "You were not the attacker," he says. "You were merely the last to fall for the lie. But the real killer is someone else—Alphonse Duret. He used the soldier's identity to scare people, to exact revenge. He killed the soldier. Then, he staged a second death to look like a self-defense claim."  

Lacheneur looks stunned. "But why me?"  

"Because you were his last target," Murdoch says. "He wanted to make you suffer like your family did. He wanted to feel power, even if it was only an illusion."

Murdon leaves the station and walks to the outskirts of Paris. He finds Alphonse Duret hiding in a cellar. The man is gaunt, his eyes wild.  

"Why?" Murdoch asks.  

Duret smiles bitterly. "Because I was forgotten. Because I had nothing. The war took everything. I became the ghost. The Prussian Shadow. I made people fear me. I made them feel what I felt."  

Murdon arrests him.

Back at the bar, Murdoch shows the barkeeper a full reconstruction of the crime. He explains the staged deaths, the use of the coat, the psychological manipulation.  

Pauline nods. "He was always strange. I should have known."  

Murdon closes his notebook. "People fear what they do not understand. He made them afraid of a ghost. But ghosts don't bleed. They don't breathe. They don't exist."

The final report is filed. The deaths are declared the result of a lone killer using a stolen identity to enact personal revenge. The soldier had no connection to the Prussian army; the coat was a costume.  

Lacheneur is cleared of all charges. He leaves the station with a quiet, weary sigh.

Murdon walks home, the city at his back. He pauses in a quiet square, watching the evening light. He pulls out a small, worn photograph from his coat pocket. It shows a younger version of himself with a group of boys—his first students in the art of observation and deduction.  

He smiles faintly.

The next morning, the newspapers report the case. The Journal de Paris writes: "A tragic tale of identity, revenge, and illusion. Thanks to the tireless work of Inspector William Murdoch, the truth has prevailed."  

Murdon reads the article in silence. He does not believe in heroes. He believes in facts.

Murdon stands at the edge of the Seine, watching the river. He thinks of the soldier's brother. Of the coat. Of the man who became a ghost.  

He turns and walks into the city, where another mystery waits.

premise: On the morning of the annual harvest festival, the mayor's daughter is found dead at the center of the abandoned village church. Her body is arranged atop the altar and surrounded by ritual symbols. The building had been sealed for decades, with its only door secured by a heavy chain and padlock on the outside, and the snow around it left completely undisturbed. Just before 3:00 a.m., during a brief power outage, several villagers reported hearing the ancient church bell ring once, despite the bell's mechanism having been declared inoperable many years ago. At dawn, when the door was found still locked, there were no signs of forced entry, no broken windows, and no footprints anywhere near the church. title: The Bell at Three-Seven
events: William Murdoch stood at the edge of the snow-covered field, his gloved hands in his coat pockets, gazing at the abandoned church. The mayor's daughter, Elise Langford, lay on the altar, her face eerily serene, surrounded by ancient symbols carved into the stone floor. Murdoch crouched near the church's entrance, running a gloved hand over the chain and padlock. He examined the hinges and the surrounding snow.

"You said the door was locked from the outside when you found her?" he asked the village constable, a man named Tobias Finch.

title: The Bell at Midnight
events:
William Murdoch arrived at the edge of the frozen village square just as the first light of dawn crept over the hills. The snow lay undisturbed, save for the footprints of the night before. The mayor's daughter, Eliza, had been last seen at 2:00 a.m., waving goodbye to a group of young friends. The constable, Thomas Greaves, stood nearby, his breath forming white clouds in the air.

"I swear, Inspector, she left with a smile. She said she was going to the old church to pray," Greaves said, rubbing his gloved hands together. "The cameras were working fine until just before 3:00. Then there was a power cut. The bell rang once during it."

Murdoch nodded slowly. "And the cameras didn't capture anything during the outage?"

"No, and the town's generator was off-line for maintenance. No one saw her go in."

He looked toward the distant church, shrouded in mist and silence.

Murdoch approached the church. The heavy chain and padlock were intact. He crouched to inspect the snow. It was untouched. No prints, no disturbances. He took a small notebook and sketched the area.

"Impossible," Greaves muttered. "No one could have entered and left without a trace."

Murdoch didn't respond immediately. He examined the padlock closely. "The lock is not new, but the chain shows no signs of wear. It was resecured recently."

"By who?"

"Perhaps by the person who wanted to make it look like no one could have entered."

Inside the church, the air was cold and stale. The altar was the focus of the room. Eliza's body lay arranged with deliberate care, her arms folded, her face serene. Ritual symbols had been painted on the floor and walls in red and black.

Murdoch examined the corn doll beneath her feet. It was scorched, but not burned through.

"Ritual," he muttered. "But not random."

He also noted the shattered pocket watch on the altar. The hands were frozen at 3:17.

Murdoch examined the bell tower. The mechanism was indeed rusted and broken. But something caught his eye—a faint smudge of oil on a pulley. He took a magnifying glass and found a small, recent scratch on the rope.

"Someone tested the bell recently," he said to Greaves, who looked uneasy. "Perhaps to make sure it could be rung."

Greaves frowned. "Why would anyone do that?"

"To stage a moment, perhaps. To give the appearance of something impossible."

Murdoch questioned Eliza's friends at the town hall. They were a mix of teens and young adults, all with alibis that fit neatly into the timeline. But one girl, Lila, hesitated when asked about the corn doll.

"It was her idea," Lila said. "She loved the harvest rituals. She made the doll herself."

Murdoch examined the doll more carefully. The corn was dried but not aged. It had been made recently.

"Who taught her to make this kind of doll?"

"No one. She read about them in old books."

He noted the subtle inconsistencies in her answers and made a mental note.

At the constable's station, Murdoch reviewed the power outage records. The generator had been off-line for scheduled maintenance, but he noticed a discrepancy in the logs. The timing of the outage had been recorded as exactly 3:00 to 3:15 a.m.

He frowned. "But the bell rang once, at the beginning of the outage."

Greaves shrugged. "We don't have a record of that. It was just a sound."

Murdoch took a closer look at the logs. "And the power was restored at 3:15? No one checked to see if it was intentional?"

"No one thought to."

Murdoch returned to the church and took more photographs. He documented the position of the body, the symbols, and the doll. He also took a sample of the red paint from the symbols and a swab of the blood near the altar.

Later, in his temporary lab, he used early blood analysis techniques and found it was not Eliza's. The paint, he determined, was a mix of cornmeal and iron oxide.

He also examined the scorched corn doll under a microscope. There were tiny burn marks, consistent with a controlled flame—like a candle or alcohol.

Murdoch met with the village elders to ask about the old rituals. An elderly man, Father O'Connell, spoke of a forgotten tradition of the "Harvest Veil," a custom where a maiden would be symbolically "taken" by the church during the festival to ensure a bountiful season.

"It was a symbolic act," O'Connell said. "But it was thought to be dangerous. Some believed it could summon something... unnatural."

Murdoch listened intently. "But no one believed in it anymore."

"Not officially. But in the village, old things linger."

Murdoch returned to the church and began a reconstruction. He noted the exact height of the altar and the angle of the light at 3:17 a.m. He placed a dummy in the same position and tested the bell mechanism.

Then, he discovered something unusual. The bell, though rusted, could be manually rung using a hidden lever near the base of the tower. It required strength and a precise movement.

He also noticed that the altar was slightly higher than the surrounding floor, and the corn doll was placed in a way that created a visual line to the bell rope.

Murdoch confronted Lila again. This time, he showed her the photograph of the doll and asked her to replicate it.

She hesitated. "Why would I need to?"

"Because I suspect you knew how to stage what happened. The doll, the time of death, the bell..."

She broke down. "She wanted to do it. She believed in the old ways. I helped her. We thought it was a way to bring the village together. We wanted to revive the festival with a real ritual."

"And the bell?"

"I rang it. I had to. It was part of the plan. The power was cut to make it look like it rang on its own."

Murdoch returned to the church with Lila and Greaves. They watched as he demonstrated the bell mechanism. With a practiced pull, the bell rang once—just like that night.

He turned to them. "Eliza died of a heart condition. She likely had a severe arrhythmia during the ritual. She collapsed on the altar. Lila, thinking the ritual failed, panicked and locked the door behind her."

"But the snow?" Greaves asked.

"She came through the church from the back, where the snow had been cleared by maintenance workers. She left the church through a hidden door into the tower, then climbed down and reentered the square undetected."

The village held a quiet memorial for Eliza. The festival continued, but with a new understanding of the past. Lila was spared prosecution for lack of intent, but she vanished soon after.

Murdoch, as he often did, remained alone in his office, reviewing the case one final time. He noted the subtle patterns in human behavior, the way belief could shape reality, and how the past could still echo in the present.

He closed the case file and looked out the window. The snow was falling again.

title: The Bell at Three-Seventeen
events: William Murdoch arrived at the church just after dawn. The snow around the building was pristine, untouched, as if no one had walked near it. The mayor's daughter, Lillian Ashford, lay on the altar, her arms arranged in a cruciform posture, a scorched corn doll at her feet. A shattered pocket watch lay beside her, its hands frozen at 3:17 a.m. The bell above had not rung in decades, but several villagers had heard it ring once just before three. Murdoch knelt, inspecting the scene with a careful eye. "No forced entry," he murmured. "And no footprints. That means someone came and went—or entered without disturbing the snow."

Murdoch examined the door. The chain and padlock were still intact, and the snow outside showed no signs of disturbance. He ran his gloved fingers along the wood and found a faint indentation near the latch. "This door didn't open and close like a normal door," he said to the constable, who had arrived with him. "It was moved slightly from the inside, perhaps with something placed behind it."

Back at the station, Murdoch reviewed the security footage from the town square. Lillian was seen at 2:00 a.m., saying goodbye to her friends. The constable, a man named Harold Griggs, confirmed he had watched her leave. "She didn't seem disturbed," he said. "Just tired, maybe. She said she was going to bed."

Murdoch paused the footage. "And the power went out shortly after?" he asked.

"Just before 3:00," Griggs nodded. "A few minutes. I lost the light in my patrol car."

Murdoch visited the church bell tower. The mechanism was rusted and jammed, and the rope had long since rotted. He climbed to the top and examined the pulley system. "This wouldn't have rung under normal use," he said. "Unless someone pulled it from the inside, with weight behind it."

He interviewed the mayor, who was distraught. "Lillian was a good child," she said. "She had no enemies. This must be some kind of... ritual. A pagan thing." She pointed to the symbols on the floor. "They don't make sense. But they look like they mean something."

Murdoch traced the symbols with his eyes. "These are not pagan," he said. "They are geometric. Precise. Possibly a code."

Murdoch revisited the church and took detailed notes of the symbols. He noticed that the corn doll was not just burned—it was seared, the edges crisped as if from a very hot flame. He also noted the position of the shattered watch. "The watch was on the floor when it stopped," he said. "It was not dropped. It was placed."

At the crime lab, Murdoch used a new technique to analyze the scorch marks on the corn doll. He discovered the burn was caused by a focused heat source—like a magnifying glass. "She was not killed in the church," he realized. "She was brought there after death. The burn was part of a performance."

Murdoch spoke with the village's only optician, who had sold a pair of reading glasses to someone the day before. "A tall, thin man in his thirties," the optician said. "He claimed they were for a relative with bad eyes."

Murdoch frowned. "Did he mention where he was going?"

"To the harvest festival. He said he wanted to see the church again. Said it reminded him of his youth."

Murdoch reconstructed the timeline. The power outage allowed for the bell to be rung from the inside. The door had to have been left slightly open, not to allow entry, but to be closed from the inside. The only way to do that without disturbing the snow was to use a counterweight system. The bell's mechanism could serve as the counterweight.

He tested the theory by placing a small weight inside the tower and using the bell rope to pull it up. The door, connected by a system of pulleys and strings, closed with the smallest shift.

The suspect was identified as Reverend Elias Thorne, the village's reclusive former priest. He had left the village years ago but had recently returned, claiming to be collecting memories for a book. Murdoch confronted him at his cottage.

"I didn't kill her," Thorne said. "I only wanted to restore the ritual."

"You didn't restore it," Murdoch said. "You performed it. You used the bell, the symbols, the corn doll. And you placed the watch. You wanted it to look like a ritual murder."

Murdoch examined Thorne's belongings and found a journal. It described a ritual performed every harvest, but only when a girl of the mayor's house was chosen. The ritual, he believed, would bring prosperity to the village. He had killed Lillian to complete it, but he had also staged the scene to appear as if the church itself was responsible.

"Why the bell?" Murdoch asked.

"To announce the rite. It had to be done at 3:17 a.m., when the veil was thin."

Murdoch returned to the church to reconstruct the scene. He used the bell mechanism to close the door, placed a body on the altar, and arranged the symbols. The corn doll was burned with a magnifying glass, the watch placed where it would stop at 3:17. The result was the same as the crime scene—except that now, it was understood.

At the trial, Murdoch presented his findings. The villagers, many of whom still believed in the old rituals, were stunned. The mayor, though heartbroken, admitted that some traditions had been kept in secret. Thorne was found guilty, not of murder, but of staging a ritualistic performance that led to death.

After the trial, Murdoch sat by the church one last time. The snow had fallen again, covering the footprints and the symbols. He lit a cigarette and watched the wind sweep across the ground.

"She didn't deserve to die," he said quietly. "But she was chosen. And he followed through with what he believed was destiny."

He crushed the cigarette beneath his boot and left the church behind.

In the end, the village changed. The old rituals were abandoned, and the church remained sealed. But for Murdoch, it was another case that reminded him of the power of observation, the danger of belief, and the fragile line between justice and superstition.

He wrote it all down, carefully, in his journal.

title: The Bell at Three-Thirty-Seven
events: The village of Eldergrove, nestled in the highlands, is cloaked in early autumn snow. At dawn, the mayor's daughter, Eliza Dunwoody, is discovered lifeless in the sealed, abandoned church. The door is locked from the outside, untouched by footprints or signs of forced entry. He turns to William Murdoch, the visiting investigator. "You must find the truth."

Murdoch examines the church's interior with a forensic eye. He photographs the crime scene meticulously. "The bell," he murmurs, "is it truly inoperable?" He notices a faint, almost imperceptible line on the bell's rope—like something has recently been tied to it. "The villagers heard the bell ring once," he says. "But if the mechanism is broken, the only way it could ring is if something... pulled it."

At the town hall, Murdoch reviews security footage. The last sighting of Eliza is at 2:00 a.m., in the square, hugging friends. The camera cuts out at 3:00 a.m. due to a power outage. The constable, Tom Hargrave, is asked about the outage. "Yes, sir. The generator failed. I didn't go near the church. Too far from the square, and the snow was too deep."

Murdoch visits the village blacksmith, Gideon Lark, who used to maintain the church's mechanisms. "The bell? That's been rusted shut for years. No one could ring it unless they had a tool to force the clapper. But that tool's been missing for decades." Murdoch notices something odd—Lark's hands are too clean for a man who works with iron.

The corn doll is examined. It's made from dried stalks and tied with frayed red string. Murdoch takes samples of the string and compares it to the bell rope. "Same material," he notes. "Same wear. Same knot." He also finds a faint smudge of charred wax on the doll's base. "This wasn't just a symbol. It was used in a ritual."

Murdoch interviews Father Tobias, the reclusive former priest of the church. "The rituals..." the old man murmurs, "were a kind of warning. The old gods don't like change. But Eliza... she was curious. She came to the church often. She wanted to understand."

"Did she ever speak of a time she wanted to stop time?" Murdoch asks. The priest pauses. "Once. She said, 'If I could just... pause the world for a moment, I could see everything.'"

The pocket watch is examined by a horologist. Murdoch learns that it was a custom piece—its mechanism could be manually stopped and started. "It's not broken," the horologist says. "It was stopped at 3:17 a.m. by someone who knew exactly what they were doing."

Murdoch looks at the shattered case and notices a small fingerprint. "This is not a victim's print. It's someone else's. The last person to touch this."

Murdoch interviews Eliza's closest friend, Clara Wren, who insists, "Eliza was never into that old nonsense. She laughed at the legends. The corn doll? She just made it for fun during the festival. But... something happened that night. I felt it."

Murdoch asks about Eliza's recent behavior. "She was... restless. Like she was waiting for something. She used to say, 'When the bell rings, I'll know.'"

At the power company, Murdoch finds that the outage was not a failure—it was a manual shutdown. The switch was pulled at 3:00 a.m. by someone with access to the control room. The only people with such access were the village engineer, Malcolm Grange, and the mayor's assistant, Dorothy Linney.

Murdoch questions them both. Dorothy is evasive. Malcolm claims he was asleep. But both of their watches are set to 3:17.

Murdoch returns to the church. He walks in, locks the door behind him, and begins to experiment. He ties a rope to the bell and uses the corn doll's string to replicate the knot he found. He places a watch at 3:17, and steps carefully through the snow. "If someone wanted to fake a locked-room murder," he mutters, "they'd need to stage every detail. Including a power outage to clear the cameras."

Murdoch confronts Dorothy Linney. "You orchestrated the power outage, cut the cameras at 3:00 a.m., and used the blackout to plant Eliza in the church. You needed to make it look like the bell rang on its own, that time stopped. You staged the watch, the doll, the symbols. But you forgot one thing."

"What?" she asks, her voice trembling.

"You forgot that Eliza was not your victim."

Murdoch reveals the truth. Eliza had discovered Dorothy's plot to frame the mayor for a land deal gone wrong. Dorothy wanted to force Richard Dunwoody to resign. To do so, she needed proof that he was involved in a ritualistic crime. So she made one. She lured Eliza to the church, staged the ritual, and locked it up, using the power outage to cover her tracks. The watch was stopped at 3:17 to indicate the exact time of death—which never actually occurred.

Eliza was alive. She had faked her death using a staged body and a timed power failure. But Dorothy discovered the deception too late. In a panic, she tried to make the crime real. She lit the doll, set the bell to ring, and left the watch to tell the time of death.

Murdoch walks with the mayor through the village square. "She's safe," he says. "She's in hiding. She's been watching, waiting. She wanted the truth to come out naturally, not through a confession."

The mayor nods. "She always had a scientific mind. Like you."

Murdoch smiles faintly. "She just liked to experiment. With people. With time. With truth."

The village holds the harvest festival as planned. The church remains sealed, a silent monument to the events. The mayor thanks Murdoch for revealing the truth. "You saw what no one else did," he says.

Murdoch shrugs. "I just looked at the evidence. And I asked the right questions."
Later, Murdoch sits by the fire in a quiet inn. He opens a journal, writes a few lines, then closes it. "The truth is never as simple as it seems," he says to himself. "But it always leaves a mark."

The next morning, a letter arrives for the mayor. In Eliza's handwriting: "The harvest is just beginning. The truth is sown. Now let it grow."

Murdoch reads it and smiles. "A good student," he says, and lights a candle.
The case is closed. But the village remains changed. The mayor vows to be more transparent. The church is left untouched. And the bell remains silent—until next time.
Murdoch boards the train to the next town. He looks out the window one last time. "Every village has its ghosts," he mutters. "Even the ones that aren't real."

title: The Bell That Sang at Three
events:
William Murdoch, a lean, sharp-eyed investigator with a quiet demeanor, arrives in the village of Elmsworth on a crisp autumn morning. His daughter, Eliza Mayfair, was found dead at the abandoned church. The constable, Mr. Halden, approaches Murdoch with a grim expression.

"She was last seen at 2:00 a.m.," Halden says, "with friends. The security cameras and I saw her. Then at 2:55 a.m., there was a power cut. The church bell rang once. It hadn't worked in a decade. By 3:17 a.m., she was dead at the altar."

Murdoch nods. "I'll need to see the church."

The mayor's wife whispers, "It's haunted, sir. No one goes there."

Murdoch's eyes flicker. "Not haunted, ma'am. Just misunderstood."

At the church, Murdoch examines the door. The padlock is still on the outside. The snow remains undisturbed. He kneels, running gloved fingers through the powder.

"No footprints," he murmurs. "No signs of forced entry."

He peers through a cracked window. Inside, the altar is stained with something dark. A corn doll lies scorched at the base of a statue. The shattered pocket watch glints in the morning light.

Halden says, "She was there. No one else could have been. Unless—" He hesitates.

"Unless?" Murdoch presses.

"Unless the devil himself walked through walls."

Murdoch's lips press into a thin line. "Let's not assume the devil was involved. Let's assume logic is."

Back at the mayor's house, Murdoch reviews the security footage. The video shows Eliza waving goodbye at 2:00 a.m., then walking toward the church. The footage cuts out at 2:55 a.m. The power outage lasted 12 minutes.

He asks, "Did anyone see her after that?"

A villager, Mrs. Rook, speaks up. "I heard the bell ring once. I thought it was a prank. But the bell hasn't worked since the war."

Murdoch scribbles notes. "The bell. That's interesting. The mechanism was damaged, yes?"

Halden nods. "The rope was cut. The wheel rusted shut."

Murdoch hums. "Then how did it ring?"

Murdoch visits the church again in the afternoon. He photographs the altar, the scorched doll, and the shattered watch. He uses a magnifying lens and a small chemical kit to test the stains near the altar.

"It's not blood," he says, frowning. "It's something else. Maybe ink."

He lifts the broken watch. The hands are frozen at 3:17. He checks the back. No tampering. The battery is dead.

He walks to the bell tower. The rope is indeed cut, and the wheel is rusted. But he notices something odd: the rope has frayed ends, not cut cleanly.

"Someone pulled this rope before it broke," he says to Halden.

"Impossible. It was inoperable."

"Not impossible. Just unlikely."

Murdoch interviews Eliza's friends at the festival. A girl named Lila, her closest confidante, is shaken but cooperative. She tells him Eliza was fascinated with old rituals and had been collecting symbols and objects for weeks.

"She was planning something," Lila says. "Something for the harvest."

Murdoch asks, "Did she mention the church?"

Lila nods. "She said the old church was a place of power. That the bell could be woken if you knew how."

Murdoch jots this down. "And you don't believe it?"

Lila smiles weakly. "I didn't. But Eliza believed in many things. Some people thought she was just curious. Others thought she was mad."

Later that evening, Murdoch is in the mayor's study again. He spreads out his notes: the power outage, the bell's ring, the unbroken lock, the undisturbed snow, the timing of the watch.

He looks at the clock. 3:17 a.m. He hums to himself.

Halden enters, holding a report. "The power company says the outage was caused by a fault at the transformer. But they found no damage."

Murdoch frowns. "No damage? Then why did it go out?"

Halden shrugs. "Maybe it was just a glitch."

Murdoch's eyes narrow. "No. Someone cut the power deliberately."

He places a small device at the base of the bell tower and walks back to the altar. He examines the corn doll more closely. It's made of dried corn, but the scorch marks are uneven.

He lifts it carefully and notices a thin wire running along the base, leading toward the altar.

He follows the wire.

It leads to a hidden compartment beneath the altar. Inside, he finds a small clockwork mechanism and a set of gears. The gears are labeled with numbers and a date: October 11th.

The date of the festival.

Murdoch returns to the village and interviews the clockmaker, an elderly man named Herrick. He shows him the gears.

Herrick's eyes widen. "These were made for the old mayor—the previous mayor, not this one. He was into these things. Rituals. He wanted the bell to ring once, at exactly 3:17 a.m., as a kind of... homage."

Murdoch raises an eyebrow. "He never succeeded?"

Herrick nods. "The mechanism was damaged in a fire. But he never gave up. The mayor was obsessed."

Murdoch files this away. "And did he pass on his interest?"

Herrick hesitates. "To his daughter. Eliza. She was his pride. She followed in his footsteps."

The next day, Murdoch visits the village library. He finds old newspapers and photographs of the previous mayor and his daughter. In a faded article, he reads about the mayor's attempt to revive the church as a ritual site.

He flips through a journal left in the mayor's study. Notes on the bell, the timing of 3:17 a.m., and a phrase: The soul must be sealed at the hour of the moon's eye.

Murdoch scribbles in his notebook. He begins to connect the dots.

At the mayor's house, Murdoch confronts the mayor. The man is defensive.

"Eliza was curious, yes, but she was not dangerous."

Murdoch shows him the gears. "She was following in her father's footsteps. She wanted the bell to ring at 3:17 a.m. She found a way."

The mayor pales. "She would never have—"

"She did," Murdoch says. "But she didn't die. She arranged to die."

The mayor looks confused. "How?"

Murdoch steps closer. "By making it look like a ritual murder. A sacrifice. To honor the old mayor and his obsession."

At dawn, Murdoch returns to the church. He walks slowly to the altar. He places a hand on the shattered watch and speaks.

"Eliza set the watch to stop at 3:17. She used the power outage to cut the circuit and trigger the bell's mechanism. She arranged her own death to complete the ritual in her father's memory."

He pauses. "She didn't want to die. She wanted to be remembered as a martyr to the old ways."

He kneels and presses a button on the hidden mechanism. The gears begin to turn. The bell groans and rings once.

The sound echoes through the empty church.

At the village square, Murdoch addresses the gathered crowd. The mayor stands beside him, his face weary.

"Eliza Mayfair did not die by murder. She died by her own hand, in a ritual she had prepared for months. She wanted to be remembered. She wanted to honor her father's legacy."

The crowd murmurs.

"She was not mad. She was a girl with a deep belief in something that many of you had forgotten."

He steps back. "The church was not haunted. It was a stage. And Eliza was the performer."

Later, at the mayor's house, Murdoch finds Eliza's journal. The final entry reads: At 3:17, the bell rings. I am free. I am remembered.

He closes the book and places it on the table.

He looks out the window at the church. The snow has settled again, untouched.

He turns to the mayor. "You should let her rest in peace."

The mayor nods. "I will."

As Murdoch prepares to leave, the mayor offers him a cup of tea. They sit in silence for a moment.

"She was a good girl," the mayor says.

Murdoch sips the tea. "She was trying to be something more."

The mayor smiles faintly. "And you always see the truth in the details, don't you?"

Murdoch nods. "Only because I look for them."

As Murdoch walks through the village toward the road, he pauses at the edge of the square. He looks back once more at the church.

He smiles faintly, as if to himself.

He had solved the case, not with brute force or instinct, but with observation, logic, and the patient unraveling of a mystery that only a few could see.

And in doing so, he had honored the memory of a girl who had, in her final act, tried to be remembered.

premise: On the morning of the annual harvest festival, the mayor's daughter is found dead at the center of the abandoned village church. Her body is arranged atop the altar and surrounded by ritual symbols. The building had been sealed for decades, with its only door secured by a heavy chain and padlock on the outside, and the snow around it left completely undisturbed. Her last confirmed sighting was at 2:00 a.m. in the town square, where she said goodnight to friends under the observation of both security cameras and the village constable. Just before 3:00 a.m., during a brief power outage, several villagers reported hearing the ancient church bell ring once, despite the bell's mechanism having been declared inoperable many years ago. At dawn, when the door was found still locked, there were no signs of forced entry, no broken windows, and no footprints anywhere near the church. Inside, the only clues are a single scorched corn doll at the girl's feet and a shattered pocket watch, its hands stopped at exactly 3:17 a.m.
title: The Clock of St. Cuthbert's
events:
The morning sun filtered through a thin layer of clouds, casting a pale light over the snow-draped village of Ashford. The annual harvest festival had been in full swing the night before, but now the streets were eerily quiet. At the center of the village square, villagers gathered in a hushed circle around the mayor and the constable. The mayor's daughter, Eliza Langley, lay dead in the locked church, arranged on the altar with ritual symbols drawn around her.

William Murdoch, the town's renowned investigator, arrived with his coat pulled tight against the cold. His sharp eyes, already scanning the scene for details others might miss, noted the padlock, the undisturbed snow, and the absence of footprints or forced entry.

Inside the church, Murdoch examined the altar. Eliza's body was posed with precision, her arms folded in the shape of a cross, her feet aligned with the cardinal directions. A single corn doll, scorched at the edges, lay at her feet. The shattered pocket watch beside her read 3:17 a.m. — the time, Murdoch noted, of her last known sighting was at 2:00 a.m.

"What time did the power go out?" Murdoch asked the constable.

"Right after the mayor's daughter said goodnight. Lights went out at the square and stayed off for about twelve minutes."

Murdoch nodded. "And the church bell?"

"Impossible to ring," the constable replied. "Mechanism rusted and broken for decades. No one's heard it in years."

At the village square, Murdoch reviewed the security footage with the constable. The mayor's daughter was seen at 2:00 a.m. in the square, laughing with friends. The footage ended abruptly at 2:45 a.m. due to the power outage. No one entered or left the square during the outage, and the constable confirmed he was on duty.

Murdoch paused the footage at the moment before the outage. "Who was the last person to speak to her?"

"Thomas Rye," the constable said. "He was her suitor. They had a public argument the night before."

Murdoch scribbled notes. "I'll need to speak with him."

Thomas Rye was a quiet man, well-liked but reserved. He admitted to the argument but denied any harm. "We were both angry," he said, wringing his hands. "But I would never hurt Eliza."

Murdoch noted the tremor in Rye's voice and the way he glanced toward the church. "Did you hear the bell ring?"

"I did. I thought it was the wind. No one else believed it."

Murdoch nodded. "The wind wouldn't have rung it either."

That evening, Murdoch returned to the church and examined the bell mechanism. The rope was intact, the gears silent. Yet the bell had rung once. He climbed the tower with his lantern and found a faint scent of gunpowder in the air. He tested the rusted gears and found one section unusually clean.

"This bell was moved," he muttered, running his fingers over the metal. "Someone used something... to force it."

The next day, Murdoch visited the village's blacksmith, who confirmed that a new set of gears had been crafted and installed in the church bell tower. The work had been done under the cover of snow and night — and paid for in cash.

"Who asked for it?" Murdoch asked.

The blacksmith hesitated. "A woman. Young. She looked like someone from the village. But she didn't say her name."

Murdoch's eyes narrowed. "Did she know about the bell?"

"She said it needed to ring once... at the right moment."

Murdoch returned to the church and took careful measurements of the altar. He noted that the corn doll was placed in a way that suggested it was meant to be seen, but not as a central clue. The scorched edges were not accidental — the doll had been burned deliberately.

He examined the floorboards beneath the altar and discovered a small, hidden compartment. Inside were several ritualistic items — dried herbs, a map of the village, and a journal belonging to Eliza.

The journal revealed Eliza's secret interest in old customs and her belief in a "harvest rite" to bring prosperity to the village. She had been planning to perform the rite on the night of the festival, believing the church bell needed to ring once to summon the spirit of the land.

But the ritual had gone wrong. The bell had rung — not by chance, but by design. The corn doll had been a focal point, and the pocket watch, which had stopped at 3:17 a.m., had not been broken, but set by someone to mark the time of the rite.

Murdoch returned to the village square and spoke with the mayor. "It wasn't murder. It was a ritual gone wrong. Eliza believed in the power of the old ways. But she was not alone in this."

The mayor paled. "Are you saying someone helped her?"

"No. Someone stopped her. They knew the ritual could be dangerous. They set the bell to ring once, at precisely the right moment, to break the spell."

The woman at the blacksmith's was identified as Eliza's cousin, Margaret Hensley, a quiet girl who had recently returned to the village after years away. She had found Eliza's journal, discovered the plan, and decided to intervene before the ritual could proceed.

"She didn't want to stop it," Murdoch explained to the village council. "She believed it had to be done — but in a way that would not harm Eliza. She arranged the bell to ring once at 3:17 a.m., as a signal. But Eliza, frightened by the sound, tried to flee. She was caught in the altar's trap — her own design."

Margaret was brought in for questioning. She admitted everything — her fear, her belief in the ritual, and her desperate act to prevent Eliza's death. She had locked the church from the inside after setting the bell, not knowing that Eliza would try to undo what had already been done.

Murdoch examined the lock again. "The padlock was not from the outside at the time. She locked it from within, then somehow managed to re-secure it from the outside. That was clever — and necessary."

Murdoch reconstructed the night:

- Eliza performed the ritual at 3:17 a.m., unaware the bell would ring.
- The sound startled her, and in panic, she tried to flee.
- The altar's mechanism, part of the rite, trapped her.
- Margaret, hearing the bell, rushed to the church and re-locked the door from the outside before anyone could enter.
- The power outage masked the bell's sound and the movement inside the church.
- The scorched corn doll and the shattered watch were the only physical remnants of the ritual.

As the villagers mourned, the constable asked Murdoch, "How do you always see what others miss?"

Murdoch smiled faintly. "Because I look for the why behind the what. The ritual, the bell, the doll — they all fit together in a pattern. I just had to follow it."

The following morning, Murdoch stood alone at the church, watching the sun rise over the hills. He placed a single corn husk at the altar, a gesture of respect.

"She believed in something," he murmured. "Belief can be dangerous, but it can also be beautiful."

As he left the village, the constable approached him. "You'll be back next year, won't you? For the festival?"

Murdoch turned slightly, the corner of his mouth lifting. "If the harvest is good."

premise: During a packed performance at the Roman Theatre in New York City, a prominent and controversial lawyer is found dead in his seat, apparently poisoned, just before the end of the first act. Strangely, his top hat - a requirement for patrons in the expensive orchestra seats - is missing, though his coat and program remain untouched. A quick search reveals no trace of the hat anywhere in the theater, and no one in his immediate vicinity recalls him acting ill or leaving his seat. The only items on his person are a monogrammed handkerchief, a half-used ticket stub from a different show earlier that day, and a cryptic note in his pocket with just the word "Marigold" scrawled in red ink.
title: The Vanishing of the Hat
events:
The Roman Theatre in New York City is abuzz with anticipation. The audience, dressed in formal attire, has gathered for a performance of The Phantom of the Opera. Among the orchestra seats, the late Mr. Reginald D'Arcy, a flamboyant and notorious defense attorney, sits in his usual place—Row 4, Seat 2. His top hat, a requirement for patrons in this exclusive section, is notably absent. The theater staff had seen him arrive wearing it. The first act is nearly over when a usher notices he hasn't moved in over ten minutes. The curtain falls, and the lights rise to reveal him slumped in his seat, dead.

"Poison," confirms Dr. Elena Marquez, the medical examiner, after a quick inspection. "Something fast-acting. A tincture, perhaps. Nothing on the food or drink he consumed."

Columbo is summoned. He arrives in his usual rumpled suit, tie slightly askew, and with a cigarette dangling from his lips.

"Nothing's missing but the hat," Columbo mutters to the theatre manager, George Halpert, who looks pale. "No coat, no program. Just the hat. And a note, right? 'Marigold' in red ink. That the handwriting of Mr. D'Arcy?"

Halpert nods. "That's what the staff says. But he was arguing with someone backstage a few days ago. A woman. She threatened him."

"Who was she?"

"No one knows. Just said she worked in the theater."

Columbo scribbles a note. "So no one in the audience saw him act strange?"

"I don't think so. He didn't leave his seat. Just... sat there."

Colum's brow furrows. "And the hat? You're sure no one took it during the performance?"

Columbo returns to the dressing room of the theater's star performer, Eliza Voss. She is a renowned soprano, and D'Arcy had recently represented her in a libel case. He had won, but not without a bitter fight.

"Mr. D'Arcy was a thorn in my side," Eliza says, her voice trembling. "But I didn't kill him."

Columbo leans back, puffing on his cigarette. "You sure about that? Because I just found this in your dressing room," he says, pulling out a top hat—identical to the one missing from the theater.

Eliza gasps. "That's not his hat! That's mine!"

"Is it? You sure you didn't take it?"

"No! I— I was in my dressing room the whole time."

Columbo smirks. "You know, people lie, Ms. Voss. But hats don't."

Back at the precinct, Columbo reviews the note with the word "Marigold" in red ink. It is written on a business card from a florist. He calls the florist, a woman named Marigold Lane.

"I sold a single red rose to someone named Reginald D'Arcy," Marigold says. "He paid in cash. I don't remember him, but I remember the flower. It was for a woman."

"Who?"

"I can't say. He said it was for his wife. But I don't think he had one."

Columbo writes it down. "What about this note? The word 'Marigold' in red ink? That yours?"

"No. That's not my handwriting. He must have written it."

Columbo visits the theater's stage manager, Tony Marlow. Tony was the one who had seen D'Arcy arguing with the woman in the back. He also noticed the hat was missing before the curtain.

"I saw her," Tony says. "She was in the alley after the first act. I thought she was a ghost or something. She just... faded out."

Columbo asks to see the alley. He walks through it, looking up at the rooftop. A gust of wind carries the scent of marigolds. He smiles.

The note is analyzed. The handwriting is not D'Arcy's. Nor is it Eliza's. It is, however, very similar to the handwriting of Marigold Lane, the florist.

Columbo returns to her shop. "Ms. Lane, let me ask you a question. You have a name. It's Marigold. And you sell marigolds. That not a little... coincidental?"

She laughs. "I was named after the flower. My mother loved them."

"Did she ever meet Mr. D'Arcy?"

"She did. He was my father."

Columbo's eyes narrow. "So you're Marigold Lane, daughter of Reginald D'Arcy."

"Is that true? I don't know. I was raised by my mother. She never mentioned him."

Columbo paces. "But you know where he was. And why he was here tonight."

Columbo visits the old mansion where Reginald had lived before his rise to fame. He talks to the housekeeper, Mrs. Bellamy, who remembers the young Marigold.

"She was a child when he left," she says. "He was a man of words, not of action. But he never forgot his daughter."

Columbo asks about the hat. "He had a custom hat made for her one day. It was red, with a marigold. She loved it."

Columbo's mind pieces it together.

The night of the performance, Marigold had slipped into the theater disguised as a stagehand. She had access to the orchestra seats. She waited for her father. When he sat down, she approached him during the performance and slipped a vial of poison into his drink.

But she didn't kill him for revenge. She wanted to make him feel what she had felt—abandoned, unseen, silenced.

When the poison took effect, she took his hat. It was the only thing of his she had ever truly loved. Then she fled through the alley, the wind carrying the scent of marigolds.

Columbo confronts Marigold again. This time, she doesn't deny it.

"He didn't even know I was there," she says, voice trembling. "He was still the same man. Still pretending to be in control. Just like always."

Columbo says nothing for a long time. Then he lights a cigarette. "You could've just talked to him."

"I tried. He never listened."

Columbo exhales. "You know what I find interesting? That you didn't kill him in the heat of the moment. You planned it. You knew where he'd be. You knew what he'd be wearing. You didn't just kill him. You took his hat. Why?"

Marigold hesitates. "Because it was the only thing I had left of him."

The final piece of the puzzle is the half-used ticket stub in D'Arcy's pocket. It was for a performance of Carmen, a few weeks prior. Columbo checks the records and finds that Marigold had a role in the production. She was the understudy for the lead.

On that night, she had waited in the wings, watching the performance from the shadows. D'Arcy had been in the front row. He had seen her. But he said nothing.

That night, she had written "Marigold" in red ink, not as a threat, but as a silent plea.

Columbo returns to the theater one last time. He walks through the orchestra seats, the same row where D'Arcy had died. The hat is no longer there, but it doesn't matter. The truth is clear.

He stands at the edge of the stage, looking out at the audience. The stage lights flicker off and on. Somewhere in the dark, a single rose falls from the rafters.

He picks it up. It is red. And it smells like marigolds.

At the precinct, Columbo sits with Marigold. She is quiet now. She has confessed.

"I didn't mean for it to be like that," she says. "I just wanted him to see me."

Columbo nods. "You got your moment, didn't you?"

She doesn't answer. She just stares at the ceiling, the red rose in her lap.

Columbo lights another cigarette. "I used to think the truth was something you found. But maybe it's something you make."

He leans back. "You know, I always liked that hat. It was a nice one. Maybe I'll get one like it."

title: The Missing Marigold in the Shadows of the Roman
events:
Lieutenant Columbo, in his rumpled trench coat and mismatched socks, stood in the center of the Roman Theatre's grand stage, his eyes scanning the still-empty seats. The body had been removed hours ago, but the stage still hummed with the tension of the night the crime was committed. A crime scene technician handed him a manila folder. "All the usual suspects are here," the tech said. "The lawyer, Victor Langley, was a real lightning rod."  

Columbo flipped through the file with his usual absentminded air, as if the case was just one of many he had to remember. "You say he was poisoned?"  

"Cherries, specifically," the tech said. "He was in the orchestra pit, right under the stage lights. No one saw him leave his seat. Only his hat was missing."  

Columbo paused. "A top hat? You sure?"  

The tech nodded. "He had to wear it for the orchestra seats. The coat and program are still in his pocket. But the hat? Gone."  

Columbo nodded, tapping his temple. "Hm. Interesting. And the note with the word 'Marigold'?"  

"Yeah. In red ink. No one knows what it means. His wife thinks it's a mistress. The assistant thinks it's a case. No one's sure."  

Columbo shrugged. "Well, maybe we should start with the hat."

Columbo visited Langley's penthouse suite above the theater. The butler, a stiff-backed man with a name tag that read Alaric, greeted him with barely a glance. "He was a difficult man, sir," Alaric said. "Always working. Always arguing. But his hat? He wore it like a crown."  

Columbo sat at Langley's desk, flipping through a stack of papers. "I hear the hat was missing when he died."  

Alaric's eyes narrowed. "He always kept it in the wardrobe. I don't see how it could be missing. Unless... unless someone took it."  

Columbo smiled. "That's a possibility. But maybe it was never there."  

Alaric blinked. "What do you mean?"  

Columbo shrugged. "Just thinking out loud. You ever notice anything odd about his schedule the night he died?"  

Alaric hesitated. "He left earlier that day for another show. A musical. The Marigold."  

Columbo's eyes lit up. "The musical? Was he in the audience?"  

"No, but he bought two tickets."  

Columbo's pen paused. "To who?"  

"To a Miss Clara Voss. She's a stage manager there. They were... close."

Clara Voss was waiting in the green room of the Marigold theater, her face pale. "I didn't kill him," she said before Columbo could speak. "I loved him. But I didn't kill him."  

Columbo leaned against the wall. "So you were with him at the Roman?"  

She nodded. "We left the Marigold together. He had a ticket to the Roman. He said he wanted to see something new."  

"Did he act strange after the Marigold?"  

She hesitated. "No, not really. He was... distracted. But that's not unusual."  

Columbo smiled. "And his hat?"  

She blinked. "He always wore it. He said it made him feel powerful."  

Columbo nodded. "Tell me something. Did you ever notice anything odd about the way he carried that hat?"  

She frowned. "He always wore it. Never took it off, even in the theater."

Columbo returned to the Roman Theatre to speak with the usher. "You handled the orchestra pit that night, right?"  

The usher nodded. "Yeah. Langley had a top hat. It was in his seat the whole time."  

Columbo smiled. "But you didn't see him take it off?"  

"No. But the program and coat were still in his seat. Maybe he just forgot it?"  

"Or maybe he never had it on in the first place," Columbo mused. "Did he ever take his hat off at the Marigold?"  

The usher shrugged. "If he did, I didn't see it."  

Columbo thanked the usher and walked to the stage. He crouched, looking at the floor where the victim had sat. "He never had the hat," he muttered. "He had the program, the coat. But no hat. That means he left it somewhere else."

Columbo visited Langley's wife, Eleanor, who sat in a parlor filled with portraits of her husband. "He was a man of contradictions," she said, her voice tight. "He had secrets. But he was never cruel."  

Columbo looked around the room. "You knew about Miss Voss?"  

She nodded. "I suspected. But I didn't confront him. I thought better of it."  

Columbo smiled. "You ever notice anything odd about his hat?"  

She frowned. "He never took it off. It was part of him."  

Columbo nodded. "But maybe it wasn't part of him. Maybe it was a performance."  

She looked confused. "What are you saying?"  

Columbo shrugged. "Just thinking out loud."

Columboy returned to Clara's apartment. "You said he never took his hat off."  

Clara nodded. "That's right."  

He smiled. "But what if he did? What if he wore it to the Marigold and to the Roman—but didn't carry it both times?"  

Clara frowned. "He would never lose his hat."  

Columbo leaned forward. "Or maybe he gave it to someone."  

She paled. "You think... someone else had it?"  

Columbo nodded. "Maybe. And maybe that someone is the one who poisoned him."

Columbo visited the theater's prop room. "You ever lend out hats?"  

The prop manager nodded. "All the time. Especially for performances. But this wasn't from here."  

Columbo smiled. "Then where was it from?"  

The prop manager shook his head. "No idea. But maybe the hat was never his in the first place."

Columbo returned to the Roman Theatre and spoke with the bar staff. "You serve cherries here, right?"  

The bartender nodded. "Yes. They're a popular appetizer. But they're not poisoned."  

Columbo smiled. "How do you know?"  

The bartender hesitated. "Because I make them. And no one's ever been poisoned from them."  

Columbo nodded. "But what if someone did poison them?"  

The bartender looked uneasy. "That would be a problem."  

Columbo leaned in. "And who would have access to them?"  

The bartender swallowed. "The kitchen staff. The bar staff. The stage crew. And the ushers."  

Columbo nodded. "Thank you. You've been very helpful."

Columbo interviewed the theater's head ushers. "You said Langley's hat was in his seat the whole time?"  

The usher nodded. "Yes. I checked it myself."  

Columbo smiled. "And where was the hat before that?"  

The usher hesitated. "In the wardrobe. He always kept it there."  

Columbo nodded. "But what if he didn't have it at all?"  

The usher frowned. "What do you mean?"  

Columbo shrugged. "Maybe the hat was never his."

Columbo visited the Marigold theater again, this time with a different question. "You said Langley bought two tickets."  

The manager nodded. "Yes. One for Clara, and one for... someone else."  

Columbo smiled. "Who?"  

The manager hesitated. "He didn't specify. But he paid in cash."  

Columbo leaned in. "And what was the name of the person who left with Clara after the show?"  

The manager blinked. "It wasn't Clara. It was someone else."  

Columbo's eyes narrowed. "Who?"

Columbo returned to Clara's apartment and sat across from her. "You said Langley was never without his hat."  

She nodded. "That's right."  

Columbo smiled. "But maybe he wasn't wearing it all the time. Maybe he gave it to someone else."  

She blinked. "Why would he do that?"  

Columbo shrugged. "Maybe he was trying to send a message. Or maybe he was trying to cover a message."  

She frowned. "You think someone else had it?"  

Columbo nodded. "I think someone else had it. And I think that someone killed him."

Columbo confronted Clara. "You were with Langley the night he died. You said you left the Marigold with him."  

She nodded. "I did."  

Columbo smiled. "But you didn't leave the Roman with him."  

She hesitated. "I... I don't know what you're talking about."  

Columbo leaned in. "You were with someone else when Langley died. And that someone had his hat."  

She paled. "I didn't kill him."  

Columbo nodded. "You didn't. But you helped someone do it."

Columbo visited the Roman Theatre's kitchen. "You served cherries that night?"  

The chef nodded. "Yes. We always do."  

Columbo smiled. "And who prepared them?"  

The chef hesitated. "One of the apprentices. A new guy."  

Columbo nodded. "And what was his name?"  

The chef looked uneasy. "I don't remember."  

Columbo leaned in. "You should. Because he may have poisoned the cherries."

Columbo confronted the apprentice. "You poisoned the cherries."  

The apprentice shook his head. "I didn't do it. I just worked there."  

Columbo smiled. "Then who told you to do it?"  

The apprentice hesitated. "No one. I just... I wanted to."  

Columbo leaned in. "You were angry at Langley. You saw him with Clara. You wanted revenge."  

The apprentice paled. "I... I didn't mean for him to die."  

Columbo nodded. "But you did it anyway. And you took his hat to cover your tracks."

Columbo visited Clara one last time. "You knew about the apprentice. You helped him."  

She nodded. "I didn't want him to die. I just wanted him to suffer."  

Columbo smiled. "And you thought giving him a poisoned cherry would do that."  

She looked at him. "I didn't know it would kill him."  

Columbo nodded. "But you helped someone who did."

Columbo stood in front of the Roman Theatre, watching the city lights. "Langley didn't have a hat. He had a secret. And someone wanted that secret to disappear."  

He smiled to himself. "And I found it."  

The case was closed. The hat was never real. Only the truth was.
