Columbo stood near the gilded velvet curtain of the Roman Theatre, his trench coat slightly rumpled, eyes scanning the crime scene with a practiced, almost distracted air. A body had been removed, but the theater still smelled of perfume, stale popcorn, and tension. A stagehand, wide-eyed and pale, handed him a report.

"Mr. Langley, the lawyer," the man said. "He died just before the final act. No one saw it. He was in his seat, then—poof. Dead. And his hat is gone."  

Columbo nodded slowly, as if the details were too much to absorb at once. He reached into his coat and pulled out a matchbook. "Was he wearing it all night?"  

The stagehand blinked. "He always wore it. It's part of the dress code for the orchestra section."  

Columbo made a thoughtful hum. "Hm. What did he do with it before the show?"  

The man shrugged. "I don't know. I just clean up the hats in the coatroom. But his wasn't there."  

Columbo turned away, muttering to himself, "Hats are funny things... they cover things."

Columbo visited the coatroom, a small alcove behind the theater's main entrance. It smelled of mothballs and old wool. A woman, Ms. Delaney, the coatroom attendant, was still in her uniform.

"You were handling the coats for the orchestra section last night?" Columbo asked, feigning confusion. "I thought this was a fancy event. Do people even still bring their coats?"  

She smiled stiffly. "Most do. It's chilly in here at night, and the dress code requires hats and coats for the front rows."  

"Ah, yes, yes," Columbo said, pacing. "So Langley's hat wasn't here?"  

She shook her head. "No. And it wasn't in the lost and found either. I checked. It's like it vanished into thin air."  

Columbo leaned against a coat rack. "You didn't see him come in before the show?"  

She hesitated. "I saw him. He was with a woman. She had a red marigold in her hair."  

Columbo's eyes narrowed slightly, though he gave no sign. "Red marigold, you say?"

Later, Columbo found himself at Langley's office. The man had a reputation—controversial, brilliant, and unyielding. His assistant, a young man named Peter, buzzed him in.

"Mr. Langley was in court last week," Peter said. "He was arguing a case involving a woman named Marigold. A singer, I think."  

Columbo nodded, making a show of checking his notes. "Marigold, you say? Was she a witness?"  

"She was the client. He was defending her from a murder charge. She was accused of poisoning her husband."  

Columbo looked up slowly. "And what happened in the case?"  

Peter shrugged. "It was dismissed. No evidence. But Langley kept saying she was guilty."  

Columbo let the silence stretch. "Do you know where she is now?"  

"She left town. Said she was going to Europe."  

Columbo gave a half-smile. "Well, that's a shame. I would've liked to meet her."

Columie returned to the theater to speak with the stage manager, a sharp-featured woman named Evelyn Hart.

"You knew Langley?" he asked, almost as an afterthought.  

"We were... colleagues," she said. "He used to come here often. Argued with the director over the script. He was always so... dramatic."  

Columbo nodded. "And the performance last night?"  

She hesitated. "It was a dramatic one. A tragedy. But nothing like the one on stage, I assure you."  

He looked at her, his brow furrowed. "You didn't notice anything unusual about Langley?"  

She shook her head. "He seemed fine. A bit distracted. But he was always distracted."  

Columbo gave a slow nod. "He was wearing his hat, you said?"  

"Yes. But he took it off during intermission. Just before he... you know."  

Columbo's eyes flickered with interest. "He took it off? Who saw him do it?"  

"Me. He said he was feeling hot. I offered him water. He said no."  

Columbo made a thoughtful sound. "Hm. Hot, was he?"

Back at the precinct, Columbo sat in his office with the evidence spread before him. The half-used ticket stub, the monogrammed handkerchief, and the cryptic note with the word Marigold in red ink. He ran a finger over the note, then looked up at his partner, a weary but sharp-eyed veteran detective named Dobbs.

"Dobbs, what's red, toxic, and smells like perfume?"  

Dobbs blinked. "You mean the note?"  

Columbo nodded. "It was scrawled in red ink. But it's not ink—it's rose oil. A common ingredient in perfume. And in poisoning."  

Dobbs frowned. "You think someone used perfume as poison?"  

Columbo gave a small smile. "Maybe. Or maybe the perfume was just a red herring. Either way, it's a clue. And red marigolds? That's a very specific flower."  

Dobbs raised an eyebrow. "You really think it's all about the flower?"

Columbo shrugged. "Maybe not. But it's all I've got."

Columbo returned to the theater for a second visit, this time with a small notebook. He spoke to Evelyn again, this time with more questions.

"So Langley took off his hat during intermission," he said. "Did he hand it to anyone? Or did it just... fall off?"  

She looked at him carefully. "He handed it to me. He said he'd forget it later. I put it in his coat pocket."  

Columbo made a show of checking his notes. "And you saw it there?"  

"I did."  

Columbo nodded. "But it wasn't there at the end of the performance."  

"No. But I didn't see it after that. I was busy with the next act."  

Columbo gave a slow nod. "That's a shame. It could have held a clue."

Columbo visited Marigold. She was in a small, rented apartment above a theater on the Upper West Side. Her face was painted, her voice still rich, but her eyes were tired.

"I don't know why you're here," she said, barely looking up from her mirror. "I was in Europe. You can check."  

Columbo leaned against the doorframe. "You were. But you also sent a flower to Langley's dressing room the night before he died."  

She turned sharply. "What?"  

He nodded. "A red marigold. You said he always hated them. Said they were vulgar."  

She exhaled slowly. "He did. But I sent it anyway. A parting gift. A joke."  

Columbo smiled. "And you knew he was going to die?"  

She looked at him, her eyes narrowing. "I didn't kill him, if that's what you think."  

Columbo gave a slow nod. "I don't think. I investigate. And right now, I'm wondering how you knew what he was wearing the night he died."

Back at the theater, Columbo examined the coatroom once more. This time, he noticed a small tear in the fabric of the coat rack. He ran his hand over it, then looked up at Delaney.

"You said Langley was with a woman when he dropped off his coat," he said. "But what if he wasn't? What if someone else dropped it off for him?"  

Delaney's face paled. "What are you implying?"  

Columbo shrugged. "I'm just wondering. Did you see the person who handed you the coat that night?"  

She hesitated. "Not clearly. It was dark. I just took it."  

Columbo nodded. "And the hat?"  

She shook her head. "I never saw it."  

Columbo gave a slow smile. "Then perhaps someone else saw it. And perhaps someone else took it."

Columbo revisited Langley's office. He sat in the chair behind the desk, looking out the window for a long time. Then he picked up the monogrammed handkerchief, turning it over.

"There's something odd about this," he said to Peter. "It's not clean. It's been washed. And recently."  

Peter raised an eyebrow. "He always carried a clean one."  

Columbo smiled. "He did. But this one is clean because it was washed after being used. That means it was used by someone who wanted to cover up a mistake."  

Peter frowned. "What mistake?"  

Columbo shrugged. "I'm not sure. But I'm working on it."

Columbo returned to Marigold's apartment, this time with a small vial of liquid. He held it up to the light.

"Perfume, right?" he said. "Rose oil. But this is something else. It's diluted. And it matches the scent that clung to Langley's hat."  

She stared at him. "What are you saying?"  

"That you may have been wearing perfume to cover up something else. Something you put in his drink."  

She shook her head. "I didn't kill him."  

Columbo leaned forward. "Then who did? Because if he died from a slow-acting toxin, and the hat was the only place it could be applied, someone had to get close to him."  

She looked away. "No one could get close enough to him."  

Columbo gave a slow nod. "Unless they were already trusted. Like someone who worked in the theater."  

She met his eyes. "You think it was Evelyn."

Columbo confronted Evelyn in the theater. She was calm, but not composed.

"You knew Langley was wearing the hat that night," he said. "You handled it. You even said so. And yet, it disappeared after intermission."  

She didn't respond.  

"You also knew Marigold was the client in his last case," he continued. "You saw the marigold in her hair. You gave it to Langley. But not as a gift. As a message."  

She exhaled sharply. "He ruined her. He made her a joke. I just wanted him to pay."  

Columbo nodded. "And you used the hat. The only thing he never took off. You laced it with the toxin. But you couldn't do it in the coatroom. You had to wait until intermission."  

She looked at him, her eyes filled with defiance. "He deserved it."  

Columbo smiled faintly. "He did. But you didn't kill him."  

She blinked. "Then who did?"  

Columbo gave a slow smile. "You did. But you didn't do it alone."

Columbo sat across from Delaney in the coatroom. She looked tired.

"You gave Langley a drink during intermission," he said. "You said he was feeling hot. But it wasn't water. It was a diluted solution that would slow the toxin. It would give it time to build up. And you knew about the hat."  

She looked at him, her face breaking. "I didn't want to kill him. I just wanted him to suffer."  

Columbo nodded. "You did. But you didn't do it alone. You helped Evelyn cover the evidence. You handed the hat off to someone else. And that someone was Marigold."  

Delaney looked away. "I didn't know she would take it."  

Columbo gave a slow nod. "She knew what was in it. She knew what he did. And she wanted him to die."  

Delaney exhaled. "He deserved it."  

Columbo smiled. "Yes. He did."

premise: During a packed performance at the Roman Theatre in New York City, a prominent and controversial lawyer is found dead in his seat, apparently poisoned, just before the end of the first act. Strangely, his top hat - a requirement for patrons in the expensive orchestra seats - is missing, though his coat and program remain untouched. A quick search reveals no trace of the hat anywhere in the theater, and no one in his immediate vicinity recalls him acting ill or leaving his seat. The only items on his person are a monogrammed handkerchief, a half-used ticket stub from a different show earlier that day, and a cryptic note in his pocket with just the word "Marigold" scrawled in red ink.
title: The Missing Hat at the Roman Theatre
events:
The Roman Theatre in New York City is buzzing with anticipation. The velvet curtains are drawn back to reveal a grand set for a performance of The Phantom of the Opera. A sellout crowd fills the theater, but just before the final notes of Act One, the lights dim, and a hush falls over the audience. A stagehand rushes out to inform the audience of a medical emergency in the orchestra pit. Moments later, the curtain rises slightly to reveal a man slumped in his seat — prominent and controversial lawyer, Marcus Varnel — dead, his lips tinged with a blue hue. His top hat is nowhere to be found, but his coat, program, and monogrammed handkerchief are undisturbed.

"Poisoned," whispers a nearby usher, his voice trembling. "But the hat is missing... that's strange."

By the time Detective Lew Columbo arrives, the theater is a hive of activity. The theater's manager, Eleanor Whitmore, meets him at the entrance with a look of strained concern. A forensic team is already scanning the seats for toxins.

"Mr. Varnel was one of our most generous patrons," Eleanor says, her voice tight. "Always in the front row, always in a top hat."

"Interesting," says Columbo, his eyes scanning the scene. "He didn't wear it tonight, though."

"His hat?" she repeats, frowning. "I'm not sure. I didn't notice. But he always wore it. It was part of his signature look."

Backstage, Columbo interviews the theater's head usher, Gregory Price, who confirms that Varnel arrived just after the curtain went up. He was given a seat in the center of the front row, as always. A few minutes later, Price noticed Varnel taking out a handkerchief and dabbing his forehead. That was the last time he saw him alive.

"Did he seem unwell?" Columbo asks.

"No, not at all. He just looked... distracted."

"By what?"

Price shrugs. "I don't know. Maybe the play. Maybe the lights."

Columbo examines the items found in Varnel's pocket: a monogrammed handkerchief, a half-used ticket stub for a different show, and a cryptic note with the word Marigold written in red ink. He lifts the ticket to the light.

"Older than the performance tonight," he mutters, more to himself than anyone else.

He pockets the items and heads back to the main floor. Something about the missing hat gnaws at him.

Columbo visits Varnel's apartment later that evening. The lawyer's wife, Lillian Varnel, greets him at the door, her face pale.

"Marcus was a man of habit," she says. "He always wore that hat. Always. It was a part of him."

"Did he wear it tonight?"

She frowns. "I don't know. I didn't see him leave. He was supposed to come home after the show."

Columbo notices a half-empty glass of wine and a bottle of sleeping pills on the side table. He picks up the bottle, tilting it slightly.

"Did he take these often?"

"Not often," she replies. "But... he had a lot of pressure. A lot of enemies."

The next morning, Columbo returns to the theater, this time asking to speak with the costume manager, Daisy Lang, who is responsible for the props used in the performance.

"Top hats are stored in a wardrobe," she explains, showing him to a small room behind the stage. "But Varnel's hat wasn't there. It's not one of ours."

Columbo nods. "So he brought his own?"

She nods. "He always did. Said it was 'a part of the character' — whatever that means."

Columbo asks to see the hatbox, and Daisy brings it out. It's a simple box, but when he opens it, it's empty.

That night, Columbo sits in the same seat Varnel occupied, watching the same act of The Phantom of the Opera. He pays close attention to the stage lights, the timing of the music, the flow of the scene. As the orchestra begins to play the final piece of the first act, the lights dim just as Varnel had died.

He watches the stage closely. Then, he notices something. A single white marigold falls from the rafters and lands in the seat beside him. He picks it up, turns it over, and sees a tiny red smudge on the stem.

Columbo returns to the theater the next day and questions the stage crew about the marigold. They say it must have fallen from the flower arrangement above the stage — a part of the set decoration.

"But the flower arrangements were checked," says the stage manager. "No marigolds were in the set."

Columbo thanks him and walks away, deep in thought.

Columbo visits a florist who had delivered flowers for the theater's set. The florist confirms that the marigold was not part of the arrangement. But he remembers something else.

"Mr. Varnel came in a few days ago," he says. "Ordered a single white marigold. Said it was a gift. I gave him a red ribbon to tie around the stem. He didn't take it."

Columbo's eyes narrow. "You said the ribbon was red?"

The florist nods. "Yes, but he said he preferred the flowers to speak for themselves."

Columbo returns to Varnel's apartment and speaks with Lillian again. This time, he shows her the marigold.

"Marcus gave this to someone," he says. "Or someone gave it to him. But the note in his pocket said 'Marigold' in red ink. That's not a coincidence."

Lillian's face pales. "Who would give him a marigold? He never liked flowers."

Columbo notices her hesitation. "But you did. You gave him a marigold once, didn't you?"

She doesn't answer.

Columbo returns to the theater for one last time. This time, he walks up to the stage and asks for a private meeting with the lead actress, Claire Moreau, who plays the Phantom's love interest.

"She wasn't in the show that night," he says. "But she was in the theater. She sat in the front row."

Claire stares at him. "You think I poisoned him?"

"I think you had the opportunity," Columbo says. "And maybe the motive. You two had a... complicated history."

She looks down. "He ruined my life."

Columbo leans forward. "Then why leave the hat behind?"

She hesitates. "Because it was a mistake. I didn't mean for it to happen. I just wanted him to see me again. To see that I had changed."

Columbo returns to the crime scene with a final theory. He stands in Varnel's seat and closes his eyes.

"He was poisoned through the hat," he says. "The top hat. It was laced with a slow-acting toxin. The marigold was the delivery system — the red ink was the marker. It was placed on the set, fell during the blackout, and he inhaled the powder when he reached for it."

"But the hat was missing," someone asks.

Columbo smiles slightly. "Because it wasn't missing. It was taken by the killer. After the performance, when everyone was distracted. The killer needed it for the reconstruction — to prove it was a mistake."

Columbo arrests Claire Moreau. She doesn't protest. In her dressing room, the top hat is found, neatly packed in a small case. Inside, traces of the same poison used on Varnel are discovered.

"I didn't mean to kill him," she says softly. "I just wanted him to suffer the way I did."

Columbo nods. "Sometimes, that's worse."

In the final scene, Columbo returns to the theater alone. He sits in the same seat once more, watching the performance unfold. He doesn't smile, but there is a quiet satisfaction in his eyes. The case is closed, not with a dramatic reveal, but with the careful, patient unraveling of a tangled web.

He lights a cigarette, takes a long drag, and watches the lights dim once more.

Back at the precinct, Columbo flips through his notes. He adds one more detail to his case file, something seemingly trivial but ultimately crucial: the half-used ticket stub to a different show.

"Varnel wasn't just attending a performance," he mutters to himself. "He was watching someone."

He smiles, just slightly, and closes the file. The hat, the marigold, the red ink — all pieces of a puzzle that only he could see.

In the final moments, Columbo receives a phone call from Lillian Varnel. She asks for a meeting.

"I want to give you something," she says. "It's important."

When she arrives, she hands him a small box. Inside is the red ribbon from the marigold — the one Varnel had refused to use.

"He always liked the flowers to speak for themselves," she says. "I think that's what you found, in the end."

Columbo nods. "Sometimes, the flowers say the most important things."

Columbo walks out of the precinct and into the night. He pauses on the sidewalk, looks up at the city lights, and smiles slightly.

"Another day, another hat," he says to himself, and walks on.

Final Reconstruction:

Marcus Varnel was poisoned through his top hat. The hat was laced with a slow-acting toxin, which he inhaled when a white marigold, marked with red ink, fell from the stage during the blackout. The marigold was placed there by his ex-lover, Claire Moreau, who had a history of resentment and a hidden motive.

She had hoped to confront him publicly, to force him to see her again, to feel her pain. But in the chaos of the performance and the dimming lights, she miscalculated. The hat was the only evidence she took with her, intending to return it — a final gesture of closure.

Columbo, with his quiet persistence and sharp eye for the small details, pieced it all together. The missing hat, the red note, the marigold — all were clues to a crime of heartbreak and regret.

In the end, the hat had not been missing at all. It had been waiting to be found.

title: The Case of the Missing Hat at the Roman Theatre

Detective Columbo, in his rumpled trench coat and slightly askew mustache, stood at the edge of the Roman Theatre's grand stage, staring at the empty orchestra seat where the late Martin Voss, a renowned and polarizing attorney, had been found dead. The red velvet seat was still warm, and the scent of orchids lingered in the air.

"Poisoned," confirmed Dr. Langford, the medical examiner. "A fast-acting neurotoxin, likely administered through food or drink. The man was dead within ten minutes of the final act starting."

Columbo picked up Voss's program and ticket stub. He noted a smudge of red ink near the edge of the stub, and the word "Marigold" scrawled in the same red ink on a crumpled note in Voss's jacket pocket.

"Did he act strange before he died?" Columbo asked.

"Not that anyone noticed," said Detective Harlan, the lead investigator. "He was in his seat, reading the program. The next thing we know, he's not breathing."

Columbo nodded, tucking the note into his coat pocket. "And the hat? Top hats aren't optional in this section. Was it missing?"

"Completely. No one saw it leave, and the hat-check area is still sealed off."

Columbo visited Voss's dressing room, which had been converted into a private lounge for VIP patrons. The room was neat, with a single chair by the window. On the desk was a half-empty glass of red wine, a bottle of brandy, and a small box labeled "Marigold Perfume – Sample Only."

He picked up the perfume bottle and sniffed it.

"Not used on him," the coroner noted. "No residue in his system."

Columbo nodded. "So the note isn't a clue, it's a red herring. Or maybe it is a clue, but not to the poison."

He noticed a faint smudge on the wine glass. "Did he eat anything before the show?"

"Just a box of chocolates from the lobby gift shop," said the theater manager. "He bought them himself."

Columbo took the wine glass and returned to the crime scene, where he compared the smudge to the red ink on the note.

Same color. Possibly the same source.

At the gift shop, Columbo met the shopkeeper, a wiry woman named Mavis.

"Mr. Voss bought chocolates here earlier," she said, pulling out a receipt. "He asked for the ones with a marigold scent."

"Marigold scent?"

"Yeah, the ones with the yellow flowers. They have a subtle floral note."

Columbo smiled. "You must be the one who gave him the sample bottle."

"No, that came with the chocolates. It's standard for high-end orders."

He nodded. "And the chocolates... were they sealed?"

"No. We just hand them out in a wrapper. He could've opened it before, during, or after."

Columbo left, pocketing the sample label. "Flowers," he muttered. "They always bloom in the most unexpected places."

Columbo visited the kitchen of the theater restaurant. He was greeted by Chef Ramirez, a short but sharp man with a keen eye for detail.

"Mr. Voss had a custom order for a late snack," Ramirez said. "A small platter of fruit, cheese, and marigold-infused cookies. He picked it up at intermission."

Columbo examined the cookies. "He didn't finish them."

"No. But he didn't seem to have any allergic reaction. At least, not immediately."

Columbo noted that the plate had been returned to the kitchen. "May I see the wrapper?"

Ramirez handed it over. The wrapping was sealed but showed a faint smudge of red.

Columbo returned to the theater and spoke with the theater's head usher, Mr. Hargrove.

"Did you notice anything unusual with the hats in the orchestra section?"

"Not particularly. But the hats are stored in a small room near the exit. It's always locked, and only the staff has keys."

Columbo asked to see the room.

Inside, the hats were neatly arranged. No sign of Voss's hat.

"Did anyone enter this room after intermission?"

"Just the janitor. He said he was cleaning up."

Columbo asked for the janitor's name. "Mr. Delaney."

Columbo visited Mr. Delaney, the theater janitor, who was a quiet, reserved man with a habit of muttering to himself.

"I was just doing my job," Delaney said. "I went in there after intermission to clean the floor. That's it."

Columbo asked if he had seen Voss's hat. Delaney hesitated.

"I saw it," he admitted. "It was on the floor. I picked it up and put it in the room."

"Why didn't you report it?"

"I didn't want to cause a scene. I thought someone would come looking for it later."

Columbo nodded. "Did you notice anything strange about the hat?"

Delaney frowned. "It had a red mark on the brim. Like a splash of wine."

Columbo's eyes lit up. "And the inside lining... was it clean?"

"Seemed fine to me."

Columbo thanked him and left.

Columbo returned to the crime scene and sat in Voss's seat. He studied the layout of the theater, the exits, and the placement of the orchestra section. He noted how the hats were stored and how the janitor would have had access.

He thought back to the wine glass, the perfume sample, the cookies — all had a red smudge. All had a scent of marigold.

And the hat had it too.

Columbo smiled faintly. "So the hat... it's the key."

Columbo visited Mavis at the gift shop again.

"Could you tell me what the marigold scent is in the chocolates and the perfume?"

Mavis hesitated. "It's a rare extract... marigold oil. It's used in some cosmetics and fragrances."

Columbo nodded. "And does it have any other properties?"

"It's not hallucinogenic, if that's what you're thinking. But it can cause a mild reaction in some people — like dizziness or a drop in blood pressure."

Columbo's eyes narrowed. "Did you make the perfume sample yourself?"

"No. I just package it. But the label says it's from a small company called 'Golden Veil.'"

Columbo took note. "I think I'll need to visit them."

At the Golden Veil headquarters, Columbo met with the company's co-founder, Elaine Whitmore, a poised and elegant woman in her late forties.

"She was one of Voss's clients," Columbo said. "She worked with him on a high-profile case. One he lost."

Elaine's expression didn't change. "He was difficult. But he always paid his fees."

Columbo examined the lab. He noticed a vial of marigold oil on the bench. He asked if it had a side effect.

"It can cause drowsiness in high concentrations," she said. "But not enough to be dangerous."

Columbo asked if the oil was used in the sample bottle. She confirmed it was.

He smiled. "And you sent the sample to the theater as part of a promotion."

"Technically, we sent it to the gift shop. They handled the rest."

Columbo said nothing, but his mind was working.

Columbo returned to the theater and met with Hargrove, the usher.

"Did anyone else have access to the hat room?"

"Only the staff. But the janitor, Delaney, has a key."

Columbo nodded. "And Mr. Voss... did he ever speak with the janitor?"

Hargrove thought. "He asked him once why he didn't wear a top hat. Said it was 'quaint' but outdated."

Columbo smiled. "And Delaney... did he have a reason to want Voss dead?"

Hargreaves shrugged. "I don't know. But I do know he was a quiet man, and he never said much about anything."

Columbo visited Delaney again, this time with a new line of questioning.

"Mr. Delaney, I want to ask you something. Did you know that the marigold oil in the perfume sample can cause a mild reaction?"

Delaney looked surprised. "I... I didn't know that."

Columbo nodded. "And you found the hat with a red stain on it. You said it looked like wine. But what if it wasn't wine?"

Delaney's eyes flickered with fear.

"I think," Columbo continued, "you used the marigold oil in the wine. Voss drank it, reacted to it, and collapsed. You removed the hat and made it look like he had left it behind. No one would suspect a janitor."

Delaney said nothing.

Columbo leaned in. "You didn't want to be seen as violent. So you made it look like an accident. But the hat had to disappear. That's where the red stain comes in. You left it in the room, thinking no one would connect it to the note."

He paused. "And the note with Marigold... wasn't a clue. It was a distraction. You wanted people to think it was perfume, not the oil."

Delaney's hands trembled.

Columbo smiled. "But you forgot one thing."

"What?"

"You forgot the wine glass. The smudge on the glass, the note, the hat — they were all the same. And you left them all behind."

Columbo stood up. "You're under arrest, Mr. Delaney. For the murder of Martin Voss."

Back at the theater, Columbo stood before the assembled staff and the press.

"Mr. Voss was poisoned," he said, "not with a deadly toxin, but with a rare reaction to marigold oil. He consumed it through a glass of wine. The hat, stained with the same oil, was removed by the janitor to avoid suspicion. He made it look like the hat had been lost, but in truth, it was taken to protect himself."

He paused. "The note with Marigold was a red herring — but it led us to the source. The perfume sample. The chocolates. The wine. All part of the same scent."

He looked at Delaney, now in handcuffs. "He didn't mean to kill him. But he didn't stop when he should have. And that's what got him caught."

Columbo smiled faintly. "Sometimes, the simplest clues are the most dangerous."

title: The Prussians in the Fireplace
events:
The cry echoes from the Poivrière bar, a seedy establishment tucked between alleyways in the 19th arrondissement of Paris. Inside, the air is thick with smoke and tension. Two men lie dead near the fireplace, one in a state of rigor mortis, the other still warm. Another body lies in the center of the room, face down in a pool of blood. And there, in the doorway, a man clutches a bloodied knife, his face contorted with pain and fear.

"Self-defense!" he shouts, voice hoarse. "It was self-defense!"

He tries to flee, but the crowd in the bar, armed with bottles and a sense of civic duty, pins him down. As he is dragged away, he mutters, "Lost... It is the Prussians who are coming."

Meanwhile, one of the victims, a wounded man, wheezes out a name: "Jean Lacheneur... he lured me here... revenge..."

A uniformed officer steps in, calling for a detective. Within moments, Lieutenant Columbo arrives, coat slightly rumpled, tie loose, and eyes sharp beneath a tired gaze.

Columbo kneels beside the first body, a soldier by the look of his coat. His fingers trace the buttons, reading the regimental markings.

"11th Chasseurs à Cheval," he murmurs, barely audible. "French Army. Still in service, I'd say. But not in uniform. Why is that?"

He turns to the second body, similarly dressed, and then to the third, in the center of the room. The man is younger, with a face that suggests youth and naivety.

"Who are you?" Columbo asks the wounded man.

"Jean Lacheneur," the man rasps. "I'm... I'm not the killer."

Columbo nods. "You say you were lured here by someone named Jean Lacheneur. But you are Jean Lacheneur. That's a curious coincidence."

The man tries to laugh. "That's not me. I'm not him. I was just... drawn there for revenge. Against him."

Columbo leans in, voice soft. "Who was it you wanted revenge against, Jean?"

The man doesn't answer. He doesn't have to. His eyes flicker toward the fireplace, then back to Columbo, as if trying to communicate something unspoken.

The wounded suspect—now identified as Jean Lacheneur—is taken to the hospital. The two dead men are identified as Pierre Dufresne and Paul Morin, both veterans of the Prussian War, now working in Paris as mercenaries. The third, in the center, is Lucien Moreau, a young soldier from the 11th Chasseurs, still in active service.

Columbo pays a visit to the hospital the next day.

"Jean," Columbo says, sitting in a chair beside the bed. "You were attacked. You said it was self-defense. That's your story. But I wonder—do you know the man who attacked you?"

Jean looks at him. "No. I don't. I was waiting for someone else. Someone who betrayed me."

"Who betrayed you?"

"That Jean Lacheneur. He's a traitor. Sold out our regiment. Left us to die."

Columbo nods slowly. "You were waiting for him to come here so you could kill him. But someone got to you first. That's what you're saying."

Jean shakes his head. "I didn't kill anyone. I was attacked. I fought back."

Columbo leans back, fingers tapping his temple. "And yet, you were the one holding the knife when you were found. That's something to explain, isn't it?"

Jean doesn't answer.

Columbo visits the Poivrière bar again. The barkeep, a grizzled man named Maurice, remembers the night well.

"Things were tense," Maurice says. "There was a fight earlier. Dufresne and Morin were arguing. Something about money. Then they left."

"Did they know Lucien Moreau?"

Maurice nods. "He was a regular. Always with a frown. You ever see a kid with a soldier's face? That was him."

Columbo walks around the bar, inspecting the fireplace. "What kind of firewood do you use here?"

"Oak. Hardwood. It burns slow, stays hot."

"Interesting," Columbo says. "And how often do you clean the fireplace?"

"Every few days. The ashes build up, otherwise."

Columbo nods. "And there are no chimneys or other exits, right?"

"None. Just the front door and the back. The fire is just for show, mostly. Keeps the place warm."

Columbo visits the barracks of the 11th Chasseurs. He meets with Captain Remy, a strict but fair officer.

"Lucien Moreau? Yes. He was a good soldier. But he was... troubled. After the war, he became... obsessed with the idea of betrayal. He spoke of a man named Jean Lacheneur. Said he was the reason they lost a battle. That he deserted his unit."

"Did Moreau ever say he wanted revenge?"

Remy nods. "He said if he ever found him, he'd kill him."

Columbo thanks the captain and leaves.

Columbo returns to the crime scene. This time, he pays close attention to the positions of the bodies. The two veterans lie near the fireplace, and Lucien Moreau is in the center, his face calm, almost peaceful.

He walks to the center of the room and closes his eyes. "This is where he stood," he says to no one. "He was waiting. He didn't run. He was ready."

He looks at the fireplace again. "There's something about the fire."

He walks over to the hearth and notices something odd: the ashes are not spread evenly. They are concentrated in one area. As if something was placed there and then removed.

"Someone placed something in the fire," he says to the officer on duty. "And then took it out."

Columbo visits the hospital again. Jean Lacheneur is still alive.

"I need to ask you something," Columbo says. "What were you doing the night of the murders?"

Jean sighs. "I was in the bar. I was waiting. I wanted to meet with Lucien. I wanted to talk to him. Explain myself. I wasn't the one he thought I was."

"You weren't Jean Lacheneur?"

"No. I'm not. I'm just... someone with the same name. A coincidence. But he believed me."

Columbo leans forward. "And the other two men?"

Jean hesitates. "They were my... associates. We had a business. A smuggling ring. We used to work together. But Dufresne and Morin wanted out. They were afraid of being caught."

Columbo nods. "So you were waiting for them too."

Jean shakes his head. "No. I wasn't. I didn't know they were coming. But I suppose they found me. I suppose they tried to kill me."

Columbo smiles. "And yet, you were the one who was found with the knife. That's a bit strange, isn't it?"

Jean doesn't answer.

Columbo returns to the bar and questions the barkeep again.

"Did anyone else come in that night, besides the three men and Jean Lacheneur?"

Maurice nods. "One man came in early. He ordered a drink, then left. I didn't think much of it."

"Did you see where he went?"

"He went to the fireplace. Poured something in. Then left."

"What was it?"

"I don't know. Something flammable. It made the fire burn brighter for a few minutes."

Columbo writes this down. "And who was this man?"

Maurice shrugs. "I don't know. He wore a long coat. I couldn't see his face."

Columbo goes to the morgue and examines the bodies again. He notices something on Lucien Moreau's uniform: a small burn mark on the back, just above the waist.

"Did he fall into the fire?" the coroner asks.

"No," Columbo says. "He was standing in it."

The coroner looks puzzled.

Columbo continues. "The burn is on the back. That means he was facing away from the fire. And yet, he was in it. That suggests he was placed in it."

The coroner nods slowly. "That's... unusual."

Columbo visits the home of Jean Lacheneur's real namesake—Jean Lacheneur, Sr., a retired officer living in a modest flat in Montmartre.

"I'm not the one you're looking for," Jean, Sr. says. "I haven't been in Paris in years. I live a quiet life now."

Columbo nods. "And yet, your name was spoken by a dying man. That must have been... unsettling."

Jean, Sr. sighs. "It was. I thought someone was trying to ruin my name. That man—Lucien—he thought I betrayed him. That I was the one who deserted. But I didn't. I was wounded. They left me behind."

Columbo asks to see his room.

On the mantel, a small box sits. Inside is a uniform, similar in style to the one Lucien wore.

Columbo picks it up. "You were a soldier in the 11th Chasseurs."

Jean, Sr. nods. "I was. But I'm not this Jean Lacheneur."

Columbo smiles. "No. But you might have been enough of a symbol."

Columbo returns to the bar one last time. He stands in the center of the room and closes his eyes again.

"Three men. Two veterans. One soldier. A wounded man who claims innocence. A dying man who names someone who is not himself. A fire that was lit with something extra. A body burned from behind. A man who wasn't the one he claimed to be."

He turns to the officer with him.

"The killer is not Jean Lacheneur. He was the victim. The real killer is someone else. Someone who set up the scene. Someone who wanted the world to believe it was self-defense. Because it wasn't."

He walks to the fireplace.

"And the Prussians? That was a red herring. A way to make people think of war, of betrayal, of revenge. But the real reason for the murder was something else entirely."

Columbo confronts Jean Lacheneur one last time.

"Jean," he says, "you said you were not the one who killed them. That you were a victim. But I think you were the one who set this up."

Jean looks at him. "I was attacked. I was just defending myself."

"Then why was the fire lit with something to make it burn hotter? Why was Lucien Moreau placed in it, facing away? Why were you the only one with the knife in your hand?"

Jean says nothing.

Columbo continues. "You weren't waiting for Lucien. You were waiting for Dufresne and Morin. You knew they would come. And you wanted them to."

Jean's eyes widen. "What are you talking about?"

"You were in the smuggling business with them. They wanted out. They wanted to leave you behind. You didn't want to be left behind. So you lured them to the bar. You set up the fire. You lit it with something to make it burn hotter. You waited. And you killed them."

Jean shakes his head. "No. I didn't kill anyone."

Columbo leans closer. "Then how do you explain the knife in your hand?"

Jean looks away.

Columbo walks into the station and places a file on the captain's desk.

"I think we've got the real story."

The captain nods. "Go on."

"The three men were in a smuggling ring. Jean Lacheneur was the brains of the operation. Dufresne and Morin were the muscle. But they wanted out. They wanted to leave Jean behind. So Jean lured them to the bar. He lit the fire with something to make it burn hotter. He waited. And when they arrived, he killed them."

The captain frowns. "Why Lucien Moreau?"

"Because he was a ghost from Jean's past. A symbol. He wanted to show that he was still in control. That he was still the one who decided who lived and who died."

The captain nods slowly. "And the fire?"

"It was a message. To the world. That it was self-defense. That Lucien was the aggressor. That the fire was just a part of the fight. But it wasn't. It was a setup. And Jean was the one who placed Lucien in the fire, facing away."

The captain looks at the file. "You sure about this?"

Columbo smiles. "I think we've got the truth."

Columbo walks outside into the night. The city is quiet. He lights a cigarette and exhales.

"Sometimes," he says to no one, "the truth is in the fire. In the ashes. In the way things are placed. In the way people die."

He smiles slightly.

"But it's always there. If you look for it."

title: The Prussians in the Fireplace
events:
At around 10:45 PM in the fog-draped neighborhood of Belleville, Paris, a cry echoes from the Poivrière, a modest bar known for its rowdy clientele and cheap liquor. Police officers from the 19th arrondissement arrive to find a scene of chaos. Two men lie dead near the fireplace, their faces contorted in final agony. A third is sprawled in the center of the room, bleeding from a deep gash on his forehead. A fourth man, clearly the assailant, stands in the doorway, trembling and clutching a bloodied knife. He is captured after a brief struggle and mutters, almost to himself, "Lost... It is the Prussians who are coming."

A dying man, identified as Jean Lacheneur, reaches out from a pool of blood and whispers, "He lured me here... Lacheneur... Lacheneur..." before his breath fades.

The suspect, Pierre Fournier, is taken into custody and brought to the local station. He insists he acted in self-defense, claiming he was attacked by the soldier-like men in the bar. His story is muddled and incoherent. The wounds on the victims do not support a chaotic fight. Columbo arrives at the station, his coat still damp from the fog, and watches the suspect's interview with quiet interest.

"Self-defense, he says," Columbo mutters to himself, scribbling notes in a weathered notebook. "But he didn't look scared. He looked... relieved."

Columbo begins visiting the Poivrière bar. He chats with the bartender, Madame Leclerc, who remembers the night well. "It was a quiet night," she says, "until three men walked in. One of them in a soldier's coat. They had a bottle of brandy and started arguing. Then the cry came from the back. I didn't see anything after that."

Columbo notices the bar is almost empty, with only two bottles of brandy sold that night. The soldier's coat is still in the bar, left on a chair near the fireplace.

Later, at the station, Columbo questions Fournier again. He feigns confusion, asking the same questions in a different order, trying to catch the man off guard.

"What were you doing in the Poivrière?" he asks casually.

"I was... I don't know... just passing through," Fournier stammers.

"And the brandy?"

"I bought it. It was for a friend."

"Was it a soldier friend?"

Fournier hesitates. "No. Just a friend."

Columie's pen taps slowly on the table. "But you knew the soldier was coming, didn't you? You were waiting for him."

Fournier's eyes narrow. "What are you implying, Inspector?"

"Nothing, Monsieur. Nothing at all."

Columbo visits the soldier's quarters in the 20th arrondissement. The soldier is identified as Captain Étienne Moreau, a veteran of the Franco-Prussian War. His uniform is still in pristine condition, and his medals are displayed with pride.

"He was returning from a reunion," says Moreau's orderly. "He was wearing his uniform that night, and he was in good spirits."

Columbo notices a small, faded scar on the man's hand. He asks about it. "A souvenir from the war," Moreau says with a smile. "A bullet grazed me."

Returning to the station, Columbo pieces together what he knows. The soldier's coat had his regiment's name on the buttons—25e Régiment d'Infanterie. The wound on the soldier was clean, suggesting a practiced hand. Fournier claimed to be a friend of the soldier, yet he knew nothing about him.

Columbo visits the local newspaper office. He finds an old article about the 25th Infantry Regiment and a name that catches his eye: Jean Lacheneur. The article mentions that Lacheneur was a deserter, dishonorably discharged, and had once fought in the same regiment as Moreau.

Columbo questions Jean Lacheneur's widow, Colette, at her small flat. She is nervous but cooperative. "He was a good man," she says. "He didn't deserve what happened."

"Did he have enemies?" Columbo asks.

She hesitates. "Yes. The men from his regiment. They blamed him for the death of their captain."

"Who was that?"

"Captain Étienne Moreau."

Columbo leans back. "And did Jean have a reason to believe Moreau was still alive?"

Colette's eyes widen. "Yes. I told him. I had heard from a friend that he was still in Paris, attending reunions."

Columbo returns to the bar and examines the crime scene again. He notices something he had missed before: a small, faint scratch on the wall near the fireplace. It looks like a name—partially erased. He gets a cloth and some powder and tries to reveal the rest.

It reads: Étienne Moreau.

Back at the station, Columbo confronts Fournier once more. He lets the silence build, then says, "You were not waiting for a soldier, Pierre. You were waiting for a ghost."

Fournier tries to look confused. "I don't know what you mean."

"Moreau was dead before that night. Killed in 1871. But someone wanted to believe otherwise. Someone wanted revenge."

Fournier's face tightens. "I don't know what you're talking about."

Columbo leans forward. "Jean Lacheneur was not the one who killed these men. You were. You dressed up a dead body and made it look like Moreau. You had a score to settle, didn't you?"

Columbo returns to Lacheneur's widow. She is now in tears. "He thought he was avenging his name," she says. "He said he would confront Moreau and prove he was innocent."

"But Moreau was dead," Columbo says gently.

"Yes. But he didn't know that. He thought he was being haunted by a ghost."

Columbo nods. "And you helped him believe that."

She looks down. "I didn't know what else to do. He was in pain. He thought this would bring him peace."

Columbo visits the mortuary. He inspects the bodies once more. The man in the soldier's coat is not Moreau. He is older, his features more rugged. The scar on his hand matches the one in the article. The other two men are strangers to the 25th Regiment.

Fournier had orchestrated an elaborate deception. He had found a dead man, dressed him as Moreau, and used a group of strangers to stage a confrontation. When the soldier's coat was attacked, Fournier played the role of the victim.

Columbo returns to the station. He calls in the chief and presents the case. "Fournier didn't kill anyone in self-defense. He killed in revenge, believing he was avenging Jean Lacheneur. He used a dead man and a lie to justify it."

Fournier is brought in for a final interrogation. He is silent at first, then says, "I just wanted him to see me. To know I was there. That I remembered."

Columbo says nothing for a long time. Then he says, "You didn't remember him, Pierre. You remembered yourself."

Columbo returns to the Poivrière bar for the last time. He stands by the fireplace and looks around. The bar is now closed, cleaned of blood and silence. He runs a hand over the wall, tracing the name Étienne Moreau.

He smiles to himself. "Ghosts and memories," he mutters. "We make our crimes from both."

The final scene shows Columbo walking through the fog-drenched streets of Paris, his coat flapping in the wind. He pauses at a newsstand and glances at the headline: Mysterious Triple Murder in Belleville—Suspect Admits Deception.

He buys a cigarette, lights it, and exhales slowly.

"Sometimes," he says to himself, "the truth is just a story we tell ourselves to feel better."

title: The Prussians Are Coming
events:
The cry echoes through the fog-drenched streets of Montmartre. Columbo, a plainclothes detective with a rumpled trench coat and a cigarette perpetually dangling from his lips, arrives at the Poivrière bar. Inside, two men are dead near the fireplace, and a third lies in the center of the room. A man with blood on his hands and a gash on his forehead stands in the doorway, muttering, "It was self-defense." Before the police can subdue him, he runs. 

Columbo watches, his eyes flicking over the room, noting the soldier's coat, the overturned chairs, and the soot on the walls.

The suspect is caught a block away, panting and disheveled. At the station, Columbo interviews him. The man, identified as Jean Lacheneur, insists he acted in self-defense. "He attacked me first," he says, voice trembling. Columbo nods slowly, then asks, "What was his name?"

Jean frowns. "I don't know. He was a soldier, I think."

Columbo leans in. "What regiment was he in?"

Jean shrugs. "I don't know. I just met him. He wanted to fight me."

Columbo marks the inconsistency in his mind.

At the crime scene, Columbo re-examines the bodies. He notices something peculiar: the two men near the fireplace are both civilians, not soldiers. The third, the central figure, is the one in the soldier's coat. The buttons are embossed with the number 111e Régiment d'Infanterie. Columbo photographs the coat and asks the bartender, a taciturn man named Moreau, about the soldier.

"Not a regular," Moreau says. "He came in with the others. Told them a story about Prussians and revenge."

Columbo scribbles in his notebook.

Columbo visits the military archives. The 111e Régiment d'Infanterie was disbanded five years ago after being accused of desertion. Their uniforms were burned, and the remaining soldiers dishonorably discharged.

Columbo smirks. "So the coat is a prop. Or maybe a costume."

Back at the station, Columbo questions Jean again. This time, he's more direct. "You knew he wasn't a soldier. You knew what he was wearing was fake."

Jean flinches. "I didn't know. He just told me to meet him here."

Columbo nods. "He told you to come to a bar where no one would know him. You were meeting people you didn't know. That's strange, isn't it? Usually, a man wants to fight someone he does know."

Jean avoids his eyes.

Columbo interviews the bartender again. "He came in with two other men," Moreau says. "They all laughed and drank. Then the soldier said something about the Prussians and left. The others followed. Jean was alone."

Columbo writes the names down. One is Pauline, the bar's regular customer, a former actress with a flair for theatrics. The other is a man named Renard, a disgraced journalist.

Columbo visits Pauline. She's in her apartment, painting. "I used to be in the theater," she says, smiling faintly. "The Prussians, the old costumes, it's all nostalgia now."

Columbo asks, "Did you know the man who died was wearing a fake uniform?"

She stiffens. "I didn't. I just thought he was a fool. A man pretending to be a soldier out of pride."

Columbo nods. "Pride. That's interesting."

Renard is harder to find. Columbo finally tracks him to a café near the Seine. "He was a joke," Renard says, sipping bitter coffee. "A soldier out of the past. I thought it was funny. We all did."

Columbo asks, "You all laughed at him. But Jean didn't."

Renard looks away. "No. He didn't."

Back at the station, Columbo re-creates the scene. The soldier, in a costume, is mocked. Jean, silent. The others laugh. The soldier, humiliated, attacks. Jean defends himself. But Columbo isn't convinced.

Why was Jean there? Why the bar? Why the soldier?

He pieces it together slowly, like a jigsaw puzzle.

Columbo visits the hospital where the wounded soldier was taken. The man, barely conscious, mutters, "He lured me. Lacheneur. He wanted revenge. For my brother."

Columbo's eyes narrow. "Your brother?"

The soldier nods weakly. "He was in the 111e. Discharged for cowardice. Lacheneur... he was my brother's best man."

Columbo writes it down.

Columbo interrogates Jean one last time. He sits across from him, not in the interrogation room, but in his office, a mug of coffee in hand.

"Tell me about your brother," Columbo says.

Jean's face tightens. "He was a coward. Discharged from the 111e. I was his best man. I watched him die of shame."

Columbo nods. "So you found someone to impersonate a soldier from that regiment. Someone you could lure into the bar. Someone you could fight. And kill."

Jean looks up, eyes wide. "No. That's not what it was."

Columbo leans forward. "You didn't kill for revenge. You killed to make your brother live again. In his uniform. In the story you made up. You wanted to become the hero he wasn't."

Jean stares at him, silent.

The next day, Columbo stands at the bar. The bodies are gone. The fireplace is cold. He lights a cigarette and smiles to himself.

Jean was not the killer.

But he was the one who set everything in motion.

The real killer was Pauline. She was the one who dressed the soldier. She was the one who orchestrated the scene. She wanted to see the past reenacted, to relive the glory of war through illusion. The soldier was her muse. Jean was her audience.

And when he attacked, she defended herself.

Columbo arrests Pauline. She resists at first, but when he shows her the evidence—her paint brushes in the soldier's room, the costume sketches, the bar receipts—she breaks down.

"I just wanted to believe again," she whispers. "In honor. In heroism. In something real."

Columbo nods. "Belief is powerful. But it can also be deadly."

The final report is compiled. Columbo writes it with his usual care. The soldier, a struggling actor, had been coerced into the role. He was killed in a staged confrontation. Pauline, in her desire to reenact a forgotten past, became the killer.

Jean, the wounded man, was the one who had been manipulated into playing the role of the hero. He had no idea what was coming.

Columbo smiles to himself. Another case, another illusion.

A week later, Columbo is back in the same bar. It's been cleaned up. The bartender nods at him. "The Prussians are coming," he says, half-joking.

Columbo laughs. "No, they're not."

He raises a glass to the memory of the soldier and the dreamer. Then he leaves, disappearing into the night.

Columbo visits the archives at the city hall. He finds records of the 107th Regiment. The regiment disbanded in 1873, after the Franco-Prussian War. The soldiers were either killed or captured.  

But one name catches his eye—Jean Lacheneur—listed as a deserter. His regiment number matches the one on the victim's coat.

Columbo confronts Lacheneur again, this time with a copy of the soldier's uniform button.  

Columbo: "You used to be in the 107th Regiment, didn't you?"  
Lacheneur: Stiffens. "How do you know that?"  
Columbo: "Because the dead man was wearing your number. And you tried to run from it."  

Lacheneur doesn't deny it. He only stares at the button.

Columbo reconstructs the scene. The three men met in the bar. The soldier, clearly Lacheneur, had tracked down the real Lacheneur, the bookbinder. The soldier was not what he seemed—disguised as a Prussian officer in a French uniform, trying to start trouble.  

The real Lacheneur, haunted by guilt from the war, saw the soldier as a ghost from his past. The fight began. The soldier tried to kill him. Duret, a local with no connection to the war, was caught in the crossfire. He tried to defend himself, but he killed the soldier.  

The other man in the center was a witness—perhaps another deserter or a Prussian sympathizer. He was killed to keep him quiet.

Columbo returns to the interrogation room with Duret and Lacheneur. He asks them to recount the events, one after the other. Duret's story is confused, but Lacheneur's is lucid.  

Lacheneur: "He threatened me. He said he would kill me for what I did."  
Columbo: "And what did you do?"  
Lacheneur: "I deserted. I left my men to die. I couldn't stand the war anymore."  

Columbo smiles faintly.

Columbo speaks to Morin.  

Columbo: "The real killer is dead. But the real crime is alive. Lacheneur didn't kill him. He was just trying to stop a ghost."  
Morin: "A ghost?"  
Columbo: "The Prussians are in the fireplace. Not real. But in Lacheneur's mind, they were as real as the bullets he heard."  

Morin sighs.  

Morin: "So what happens now?"  
Columbo: "We let him go. He's not the monster we thought. He's just a man who's been running for forty years."

The case is closed without charges. Columbo rides back to the precinct, sipping coffee from a paper cup. He doesn't look like a man who just solved a murder. He looks like a man who just remembered something important.  

Columbo (to himself): "Sometimes you don't catch the killer. You just help them find peace."

Later that evening, Columbo visits the bookbinder's shop. He places the book he gave Duret on the counter.  

Columbo: "You ever read it?"  
Lacheneur: "No. But I think I'll read it now."  

Columbo nods and leaves without a word.

Columbo walks into his apartment, removes his trench coat, and lays it over a chair. He looks at the coat, then at the mirror. He smiles faintly.

Columbo (to himself): "Another ghost laid to rest."  

He turns off the light and goes to bed.

Final Reconstruction by Lieutenant Columbo:  

The Prussians in the fireplace were not real men. They were memories.  

Jean Lacheneur, a deserter from the 107th Regiment, had spent forty years running from the war. When a man in a soldier's coat entered the bar and threatened him, Lacheneur mistook him for one of his old enemies.  

The man, however, was not a real soldier. He was a Prussian sympathizer, possibly a spy or agitator, who had disguised himself in a French soldier's coat. He was trying to provoke unrest.  

When the fight broke out, Duret—caught in the crossfire—defended himself and killed the intruder. The third man, an accomplice to the plot, was silenced.  

Columbo, through patience, observation, and a careful reading of the past, saw the truth not in the crime, but in the man who had been haunted by it for too long.  

The Prussians were never in the room. They were in the mind of the killer.

premise: In a dangerous area of Paris, a cry is heard from the Poivrière bar. Inside, two men lie dead near the fireplace, and another is found in the center of the room. A wounded man, clearly the killer, stands in a doorway. He claims innocence, insisting it was self-defense, before attempting to flee. When captured, he exclaims, "Lost... It is the Prussians who are coming". The dying wounded man accuses Jean Lacheneur of luring him to the location and vows revenge. The dead man's attire identifies him as a soldier, with his regiment's name and number marked on his greatcoat's buttons.
title: The Prussians of Poivrière
events:
The cry echoes through the fog-drenched streets of Montmartre. A barkeep, trembling, dials for help. When Lieutenant Pierre Leclair arrives at the Poivrière, he finds three men dead—two near the fireplace, another sprawled in the center of the room. A fourth man, bloodied and disheveled, stands frozen in the doorway, clutching a jagged piece of fireplace brick. His eyes dart around, unsteady, before he tries to flee.

"Wait!" Leclair calls, blocking the exit. "You're injured. Let's talk."

The man hesitates, then drops the brick. "I'm innocent, mon lieutenant. Self-defense. They attacked me—"

He breaks off as sirens wail. Police swarm in.

At the crime scene, Leclair crouches near the central corpse. The man's greatcoat is tattered, but the buttons are still intact. He turns one over, noting the insignia: 7e Régiment de Chasseurs à Cheval. A cavalry regiment. The lieutenant marks the number in his notebook.

"Self-defense, huh?" he murmurs to the suspect, still on the floor. "You don't seem like a soldier."

Jean Lacheneur doesn't answer. He just stares at the wall.

Back at the precinct, Leclair arranges the statements. The dying soldier, Paul Fournier, had whispered to a nurse, "He lured me here. He will pay." The other two men are identified—Antoine Duval and Étienne Moreau. No military ties.

Leclair scribbles a list: One soldier, two civilians. All dead. One wounded, claims self-defense. Injured man speaks of Prussians. Why?

He glances at the suspect. "Where are you from, Jean?"

"From nowhere," Lacheneur replies, avoiding eye contact.

The next day, Leclair visits the barracks of the 7th Regiment. The captain is cooperative. "Paul Fournier was a good soldier. Quiet, but he kept to himself. He was reassigned last week due to... stress. Rumors of a romantic entanglement."

Leclair nods. "Who was he with?"

The captain hesitates. "A civilian woman. From the Poivrière. She was... trouble."

"Her name?"

The captain shrugs. "We don't keep that kind of record."

At the bar, Leclair speaks with the owner, a heavyset man named Henri. "Paul Fournier was a regular. He used to drink alone. Quiet type. But then... she came in."

"Who?"

"Claire. She worked here. Young. Pretty. He followed her one night. Never came back the same."

Leclair sips his coffee. "You think he was jealous?"

Henri nods. "She was seeing someone else. A man with no name. The kind who drifts in and out. He's here now and then. People call him 'le fantôme.'"

Leclair tracks down Claire. She's in a small flat in Belleville. She's startled to see him, but answers his questions politely.

"Paul was a good man," she says. "But he was... obsessed."

He asks if she saw Lacheneur.

"I don't know who he is. But Paul was jealous. He thought I was seeing someone. But I wasn't. I told him that. Over and over."

Leclair writes something down. "And the night of the incident?"

She shakes her head. "I was working. I don't know what happened."

At the morgue, Leclair examines the bodies again. Fournier has a single deep wound in the chest—consistent with a brick strike. Duval and Moreau have multiple contusions. No defensive wounds. Lacheneur has a wound on his arm, but nothing to the torso.

"Self-defense?" Leclair mutters. "He didn't block a blow. He didn't even try."

He jots a note: No defensive injuries. All others are dead. He was the target.

Leclair returns to the bar and inspects it again. The fireplace is cold, but soot still clings to the floor. He notices a faint drag mark from the brick to the center of the room. The brick was thrown, but not from where Lacheneur stood.

He walks around the room, then stops. The fireplace is tall. To reach the top, someone would need to stand on the hearth.

He looks around. No footprints. No sign of a struggle near the fireplace.

Leclair questions Lacheneur again. "You said, 'It is the Prussians who are coming.' What does that mean?"

Lacheneur stares at the wall. "It's a saying. A... memory."

Leclair leans in. "A memory of what, exactly?"

Lacheneur hesitates. "I was in the army. 7th Chasseurs. I deserted. The Prussians... they came. They were everywhere. I couldn't take it. I left."

Leclair scribbles in his notebook. "Paul Fournier was in the same regiment."

Lacheneur doesn't respond.

Leclair interviews the 7th Chasseurs again. This time, he asks about deserters.

One soldier speaks up. "There was a rumor. A man named Lacheneur. He vanished during the retreat. He was... broken. They say he was haunted by the Prussians."

Leclair nods. "And Paul Fournier?"

"He was one of the ones who stayed. He led a charge. They said he was a hero. But he came back changed."

Leclair writes: Two soldiers. One a hero. One a coward. They met in the bar. They met in war.

Leclair returns to the bar and stands at the center of the room. He closes his eyes. The fireplace. The bodies. The wound. The words: 'It is the Prussians who are coming.'

He opens his eyes. The fireplace. The height. The mark.

He turns to the brick. It's jagged, but not sharp. A blunt weapon.

He walks toward the hearth. The mark starts there. The brick was thrown from inside the fireplace.

He looks around. No one could reach that high unless they were already standing in the fireplace.

A memory clicks. Fournier had a wound in the chest. It was clean. Precise.

A brick. Thrown from inside the fireplace.

By someone who had been there before.

Leclair returns to the suspect. "Jean, why did you say 'the Prussians are coming'?"

Lacheneur stares at the wall. "I was scared. I thought I was back in the war. I thought they were coming for me again."

Leclair sits. "You were in the same regiment as Paul Fournier, weren't you?"

Lacheneur doesn't answer.

Leclair leans in. "You were jealous of him. You thought he got everything. The medals. The respect. You thought you were the one who should have been there."

Lacheneur flinches. "I wasn't the one who died."

"No," Leclair says softly. "But you made it look like you were."

Leclair walks outside. The Paris sky is overcast. He thinks.

Paul Fournier was in love. He was jealous. He followed Claire to the bar. He confronted the man she was seeing. That man was Lacheneur. Not a soldier. But someone who had been one.

Lacheneur had the height, the strength, the timing. He lured Fournier into the bar. He waited. Then, when Fournier was distracted, he struck.

But he didn't want to be seen. So he climbed into the fireplace. He waited. When Fournier approached, he threw the brick. It landed in the center. Fournier died instantly.

Then, to frame it as a fight, Lacheneur dragged the bodies. When the police arrived, he stood in the doorway, bloodied, and claimed self-defense.

But he had no defensive injuries. He was the killer.

And the memory of the Prussians? A trigger. A way to escape into the past. To make the guilt go away.

Back at the precinct, Leclair calls for a reconstruction. He gathers the staff and police.

He sets the brick in the fireplace. Climbs in. Kneels. The height is just right.

He climbs out, dusts off his coat, and addresses the team.

"I believe the killer was inside the fireplace. He was waiting for the victim. The brick was thrown from there. The other two men were killed first. The killer made it look like a fight. But only one of them died from the brick."

He pauses. "The man in the fireplace is the killer. He's not the wounded one. He is the one who wounded himself to look like the victim."

He turns to Lacheneur, who is watching. "You killed Paul Fournier. And you tried to kill me by making me believe someone else did."

Lacheneur, shaken, finally speaks. "I didn't want to kill him. I just... wanted him to leave. He was hurting her. He didn't know I was there. I only wanted to scare him."

Leclair nods. "And when he didn't run, you struck."

Lacheneur closes his eyes. "I didn't want it to happen."

Leclair leans in. "You didn't want it. But you did it. And you tried to hide it. Now, you must live with it."

Leclair walks through the station, back to his desk. The case is closed. The killer has confessed. But something lingers in his mind.

He looks at the photo of Paul Fournier. A young soldier. A man who gave everything. And yet, he still lost.

Leclair smiles faintly. "We all lose, in the end."

He writes one final note in his journal: Even heroes have ghosts.

He steps outside into the rain. The city hums with life. He takes a deep breath.

And walks on.

premise: On the morning of the annual harvest festival, the mayor's daughter is found dead at the center of the abandoned village church. Her body is arranged atop the altar and surrounded by ritual symbols. The building had been sealed for decades, with its only door secured by a heavy chain and padlock on the outside, and the snow around it left completely undisturbed. Her last confirmed sighting was at 2:00 a.m. in the town square, where she said goodnight to friends under the observation of both security cameras and the village constable. Just before 3:00 a.m., during a brief power outage, several villagers reported hearing the ancient church bell ring once, despite the bell's mechanism having been declared inoperable many years ago. At dawn, when the door was found still locked, there were no signs of forced entry, no broken windows, and no footprints anywhere near the church. Inside, the only clues are a single scorched corn doll at the girl's feet and a shattered pocket watch, its hands stopped at exactly 3:17 a.m.
title: The Bell at Three-Thirty-Seven
events:
Columbo stood at the threshold of the abandoned church, his trench coat dusted with snow, the padlock still in place on the heavy oak door. The mayor, a man with bloodshot eyes and a trembling voice, led him through the village square. "My daughter, Clara," he said, voice breaking. "Last seen at 2:00 a.m., then gone. The bell rang at 3:00, and the next day, she was there—dead, on the altar."

Columbo nodded slowly, stepping closer to the door. "And the bell hasn't worked in years?" he asked, more to himself than to the mayor.

"No," the mayor said. "It's been rusted in place. I saw to that myself."

Inside the church, the air was thick with the scent of damp wood and dust. Columbo moved methodically, his eyes flicking over every detail. The altar was at the center of the nave, and Clara lay in a posture of reverence, her arms crossed over her chest. Around her feet were symbols etched into the stone floor—interlocking circles, triangles, and one shape that looked like a corn kernel.

He crouched down. A scorched corn doll lay at her feet, its fabric blackened. Beside it, a shattered pocket watch. The hands were frozen at 3:17 a.m.

"Who found her?" Columbo asked, not looking up.

"The constable, at dawn. No one went inside. The door was locked."

The constable, a wiry man with a scar down his cheek, stood nearby, arms crossed. "We checked everything, Lieutenant. No forced entry. The door was still padlocked. I even called a mechanic to check the bell. It was rusted solid."

Columbo looked up, tapping the broken watch. "And you're sure it was stopped at 3:17?"

The constable nodded. "Yes, sir. I timed it with my phone."

Columbo's brow furrowed slightly. "You didn't touch it?"

"No. I just took photos."

"Hm. That's good. You know, I always forget to charge mine," Columbo mused, as if to himself.

The village was quiet, save for the occasional creak of the wind through the empty buildings. Columbo wandered through the square where Clara had been seen at 2:00 a.m. The security cameras were still up, their lenses dusted over. He spoke to the night watchman, a man with a beard and a tired voice.

"She said goodnight to a few friends," the man said. "Then walked off toward the church, maybe. But I can't be sure. The snow's covered the tracks."

Columbo nodded. "Did you hear the bell ring at 3:00?"

The watchman shook his head. "No. I was asleep."

Columbo smiled. "I often forget to set my alarm, too."

At the town hall, Columbo reviewed the security footage. The clip showed Clara laughing with friends, then walking away. He paused the video at the moment she left. Her coat was buttoned, and her boots were clean.

He rewound and played it again. This time, he noticed something—her left hand was bare, her right gloved. "Interesting," he muttered, scribbling a note in his pad.

Columbo visited Clara's house. Her mother, a tall woman with a sharp gaze, showed him around. The house was tidy, but Columbo noticed a small, homemade corn doll on a shelf. "Her favorite," the mother said quietly. "She used to make them every year for the festival."

Columbo picked up the doll. "Did Clara know anything about the church? About its history?"

The mother hesitated. "She said it was haunted. That the bell rang when it shouldn't. But I thought it was just a child's fear."

Columbo returned to the church, this time alone. He walked the perimeter, looking at the padlock once more. He touched the chain, then knelt to examine the snow. It was undisturbed.

He looked up at the bell tower. "Hm," he said to no one. "A bell that doesn't work, but rang once. That suggests a motive."

He patted his coat. "I always forget the sound of a real bell. It's a shame, really."

Columbo visited the village mechanic, the man who had supposedly confirmed the bell was inoperable. The mechanic was a stout man with grease-stained hands.

"Yup," he said, "I checked the bell last year. The clapper was rusted shut. No way it could ring without a hammer and chisel."

Columbo nodded. "And no one's been up there since?"

The mechanic shook his head. "Not since I sealed it. That bell's been silent for decades."

Columbo returned to the crime scene, this time focusing on the altar. He examined the corn doll more closely. The scorched marks were uneven, like they had been burned intentionally, not accidentally.

He crouched, then looked at the floor. The symbols were precise, but one of them was slightly deeper than the others. He traced it with his finger. "This wasn't etched with a knife," he muttered. "It was made with a metal tool—like a spoon."

Columbo sat in his car, staring at his notes. The watch was frozen at 3:17, the bell had rung at 3:00, and Clara had been seen at 2:00. He flipped through the security footage again in his mind.

At 3:17, the clock had stopped. But Clara was already dead by then.

He looked out the window. The snow was falling gently. "That's the thing about snow," he muttered. "It covers everything."

Columbo returned to the church at dusk. He climbed the bell tower with a flashlight. The mechanism was rusted, but the clapper was still in place. He examined it closely.

Then he noticed something. A small chain, barely visible, was wrapped around the clapper. It looked old, but not too old. He tugged at it slightly. It moved.

He smiled. "I always forget how loud a small chain can be."

Columbo returned to the village square, where the mayor, the constable, and the mechanic were waiting. He cleared his throat.

"Clara didn't die in the church," he said. "She died in this square, at 2:00 a.m. She was carrying a corn doll, which she lit on fire before walking away. That's why her left hand was bare."

The mayor gasped. "But she was found in the church!"

"She was moved. The key was the bell. It wasn't broken—it just needed a little help. Someone used a chain to pull the clapper. They rang the bell at 3:00, then carried Clara into the church after the power went out."

He paused. "The watch stopped at 3:17—not because it broke, but because someone reset it to that time after moving the body."

Columbo turned to the constable. "You said the watch was stopped at 3:17. You didn't touch it."

The constable nodded. "No, sir. I just took photos."

Columbo nodded. "You didn't know to look for the chain. And you didn't hear the bell ring."

He turned to the mayor. "You said you sealed the church. But you didn't check the bell yourself. You believed it was rusted."

The mayor looked down. "I... I did."

Columbo walked to the mechanic. "You said the bell was inoperable. But you didn't check it this year."

The mechanic shifted. "I didn't need to."

Columbo smiled. "No. You didn't. Because you were the one who rigged the bell. You needed it to ring at 3:00. That's when the power went out."

The mechanic's face paled.

Columbo leaned against the church wall. "You used the power outage to move Clara's body and reset the watch. You made sure no one would see you. You left the corn doll to suggest a ritual. But you forgot one thing."

He pointed at the doll on the altar. "That wasn't Clara's. It was the one from your house. The real one was with her in the square."

The mayor's eyes widened. "How... how did you know?"

Columbo smiled faintly. "Because the real one was burned. The one here was just scorched."

Columbo stepped back, crossing his arms. "You wanted to make it look like Clara was taken by someone else. You wanted to create a mystery, not solve it. But you didn't realize how much you left behind."

He looked at the watch on his wrist. "3:17. You stopped time to stop truth."

The mechanic sighed and stepped forward. "I didn't do it for revenge. I just... I just wanted her to disappear."

Columbo nodded. "I know. That's what makes it worse."

As the constable led the mechanic away, Columbo walked back to his car. He paused, looking at the church one last time.

"I always forget how quiet it gets after a case," he muttered.

He got into his car, turned the key, and drove into the snow. The bell, now quiet once more, hung in the silence.

In the final scene, Columbo is in his hotel room. He opens a drawer and takes out a small, handmade corn doll. He holds it up to the light.

"Funny," he says to himself. "You know more about people than you think you do."

He sets it down carefully and turns off the lamp.

The next morning, the town square is quiet. The festival is canceled. Columbo stands alone, watching the snow fall.

He lights a cigarette and takes a slow drag.

"I always forget how clean it looks when it's over," he says.

He exhales and walks away.
